archiveTopNews.title: Daniel Andrews says lockdown 'is working', as Victoria's daily coronavirus infections drop below 100
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria's daily coronavirus numbers dropped below 100 for the first time in 2 months. The state reported only 95 cases in the last 24 hours, the lowest number since July 5th. There were also 18 more deaths overnight, taking the state's toll to 513, and the country's to 600.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus outbreak at Frankston Hospital in Melbourne's south-east sends more than 600 staff into quarantine
archiveTopNews.summary: A coronavirus outbreak at Frankston Hospital has lead to 618 staff being furloughed according to Peninsula Health. There are currently 44 active cases among Peninsula Health staff.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria's coronavirus case numbers keep falling, as Daniel Andrews flags state of emergency extension
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria's case numbers dropped sharply with only 116 announced today. This is the lowest daily tally since July 5th, when 74 cases were announced. July 5th was also the last time the number of new cases announced was under a hundred. Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews also announced today that the government is looking at extending the the state of emergency provisions that allowed for the coronavirus restrictions for 12 more months.

archiveTopNews.title: Funding for Victorian bushfire-affected communities as premier warns upcoming summer will be a challenge
archiveTopNews.summary: The state government has announced more than $110 million for bushfire-affected communities to help their long-term economic recovery. State Premier Daniel Andrews expressed that the state will be ready to handle the upcoming bushfire season, but stressed that it would not be easy.

archiveTopNews.title: New coronavirus restrictions return in Queensland as youth detention centre cluster grows
archiveTopNews.summary: Six more cases of COVID-19 have been reported in Queenslands. All six belong to a cluster at a youth detention centre. Authorities have now moved to limit indoor and outdoor gatherings.

archiveTopNews.title: More than 18,000 Australians stranded by coronavirus are still trying to return home
archiveTopNews.summary: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have revealed that 18,800 Australians remain overseas and have had their returns delayed due to the country's cap on internation arrivals. DFAT officials warned the pariliaments COVID committee of the situation earlier today.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus health alert issued for Brisbane cafe after woman tests positive
archiveTopNews.summary: A women testing positive for COVID-19 in Japan has prompted urgent contact tracing and coronavirus testing in Brisbane. The woman had flown to Sydney on 17th August and subsequently flew to Jpan where she tested positive for COVID-19.

archiveTopNews.title: Australian government does deal to secure potential Oxford University Covid vaccine for free
archiveTopNews.summary: The federal government has announced that they have reached an agreement with British pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca to supply Australians with Oxford University's COVID-19 vaccine for free. This will only happen if the vaccine clears clinical trials. The Prime Minister also announced that the government plans to continue to negotiate with other parties as well.

archiveTopNews.title: Ruby Princess: NSW premier Gladys Berejiklian apologises 'unreservedly' for cruise ship debacle
archiveTopNews.summary: New South Wales Premier Gladys Berejiklian has apologised to individuals that may have suffered due to NSW Health's handling of the Ruby Princess cruise ship. The NSW inquiry into the ship which was the source of over 900 coronavirus cases and 28 deaths, released its results on Friday. It found multiple errors it described as "serious", "inexplicable" and "basic"

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria records 25 coronavirus deaths in Australia's deadliest day so far
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria recorded its deadliest day of the pandemic so far with 25 deaths announced overnight. More than 300 people have now died since the second wave began in Melbourne in June.

archiveTopNews.title: Hundreds of international students to return to South Australia under national pilot program
archiveTopNews.summary: A national pilot program looking to revive Australia higher education sector will see 300 international students return to university in Adelaide next month. The students from South East Asia will travel to Australia from Singapore in September. They will undergo mandatory supervised quarantine, which will be paid for the universities.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorian coronavirus response 'not doing enough' to reach key groups, Chief Health Officer says
archiveTopNews.summary: Victorian Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton has said that the Victorian coronavirus is "not doing enough," to reach key groups. Despite numerous channels and media sources to communicate information, he has emphasised that, "we absolutely always need to do more." Questions have been raised recently over a lack of community involvement in the coronavirus response, with translated campaign materials being described as "non-sensical." The translations in question have since been rectified.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorian man in his 20s becomes Australia’s youngest coronavirus death as state records 372 new cases
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria announced 372 new coronavirus cases and 14 new deaths today. The state's death tally stands at 289. Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews revealed that one of the deaths was a man in his 20s, the youngest victim of the pandemic in Australia so far.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria to spend $14 million on more multicultural coronavirus support after translation bungles
archiveTopNews.summary: The Victorian government announced $14.3 million dollars worth of funding to support multicultural communities through the coronavirus crisis. This is in response to errors being uncovered in the translations of critical health messages. Of the additional funding, $2 million will be for translation and interpreter services, $5.5 million would be for the distribution of those services and $6.9 million will be for the organisations that work on the ground.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia must place climate action at centre of coronavirus recovery, chief UN economist says
archiveTopNews.summary: In an interview with progressive think-thank the Australian Institute, Elliot Harris a UN Chief Economist, has said Australias and other countries around the world to invest in clean energy and take more ambitious action against climate change. Elliot is currently helping to lead the UN's development of policy advice for nations grappling with the pandemic. "What we’ve seen in this COVID crisis is that governments are indeed capable of really ambitious, rather unorthodox and extremely important and even massive interventions," he said, adding "I can think of no stakes that are higher than the climate crisis that we are living in right now." UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres has stressed that coal should not be part of any nation's stimulus plan, and a number of Australian business leaders have also pressured the Federal Government to invest in renewable energy.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria's coronavirus death toll climbs to 246 as senior officials grilled at inquiry
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria reported 19 deaths overnight as its coronavirus death toll climbed to 246. State Premier Daniel Andrews reported that 1,185 of the current active cases in the state are healthcare workers. Earlier in the day, Andrews Andrews faced questions at the inquiry regarding the state’s hotel quarantine program. He told the committee that ADF forces had not been offered to guard hotels at the time the scheme was introduced. Defence Minister Linda Reynolds then released a statement saying that ADF assistance had been offered to Victoria on "multiple occasions" from late March

archiveTopNews.title: Man in his 60s becomes Tasmania's first coronavirus case in nearly three weeks
archiveTopNews.summary: Tasmania has recorded its first coronavirus case in 20 days. The person is a man in his 60s who had visited Melbourne for medical treatment. He has been admitted to hospital and being treated under appropriate infection control protocols.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia marks deadliest day in the coronavirus pandemic as Victoria records 17 deaths
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria recorded 394 new cases and 17 deaths today, the country's deadliest day of the pandemic so far. Ten of the deaths were linked to aged care facilities.

archiveTopNews.title: More than 140 turned back at Queensland border in first hours of closure to NSW and ACT
archiveTopNews.summary: More than 140 people have been turned away at the Queensland border as it was closed to people from ACT, NSW and Victoria. "It's unfortunate but this is all about stopping COVID-19 coming into Queensland," said Queensland Police Services Chief Superintendent Mark Wheeler.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorian anti-lockdown protest organisers raided and arrested before dangerous demonstration
archiveTopNews.summary: Police have raided the homes of and arrested two men accused of planning an anti-lockdown protest in Melbourne. The individuals had created an event on Facebook which had 100 confirmed attendees and a further 400 expressions of interest. "This is a completely blatant breach of the chief health officer's directions and puts Victorian lives at risk," police said.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria reports 911 healthcare workers have Covid-19, after daily rise of 101
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria has reported that 911 healthcare in the state have COVID-19. The state announced a total of 450 new cases today, 101 of those are healthcare workers. Victoria’s chief health officer Brett Sutton said the numbers are very concering.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus border restrictions, NSW quarantine rules and Victoria child care measures announced today
archiveTopNews.summary: A number of new regulations have been implemented in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland.

archiveTopNews.title: Of the 15 new deaths recorded on Wednesday, twelve were linked to the state's aged-care sector.
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria recorded 752 new coronavirus cases today as well as 15 more deaths. One death was a man in his 30s, and 12 were linked to the state's aged care sector. The man in his 30s is the youngest person to die from the virus in Australia.

archiveTopNews.title: Melbourne's stage 3 lockdown prevented thousands of coronavirus cases, research data shows
archiveTopNews.summary: Researchers from the Burnet institute predicted that about 27,000 people would have been diagnosed with COVID-19 in July had the growth rate of the coronavirus continued uncheck. The actual number of cases recorded in July was about 8,000. CEO Brendan Crabb said overwhelmingly, community effort in adhering to stage 3 restrictions had a "major impact" in preventing cases and saving lives. "We can assume we would have had three to four times the number of deaths, three to four times the number of serious illnesses, so a very major impact of stage 3 lockdown," Professor Crabb said.

archiveTopNews.title: From moving house to questions about travelling to halal butchers, here's what you wanted to know about Victoria's latest coronavirus restrictions.
archiveTopNews.summary: SBS News has collected a number of common questions requested by users regarding the lockdowns in Victoria. Metropolitan Melbourne will be under stage 4 restrictions, and regional Victoria will be under stage 3 restrictions. Check the full articles for some commonly asked questions, and refer to our Info page for details regarding the regulations.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria announces State of Disaster as Melbourne enters drastic Stage 4 coronavirus lockdown
archiveTopNews.summary: A State of Disaster has been declared in Melbourne. Authorities have imposed stage 4 lockdown restrictions in metropolitan Melbourne. With 760 mystery cases around the state, state Premier Daniel Andrews has announced that the new restrictions would be in place for 6 weeks. The restrictions include a curfew from 8pm to 5am.

archiveTopNews.title: South Australian coronavirus vaccine candidate shows positive results in phase one human trials
archiveTopNews.summary: A Covid-19 vaccine candidate, COVAX-19, developed by Adelaide-based company Vaxine has shown positive results in phase one human trials. Victorian aged care residents could be included in the next stage of testing. Lead researcher Professor Nikolai Petrovsky said the vaccine candidate had been shown to be safe and to induce antibodies that attack the coronavirus that causes COVID-19."We've had no major side-effects in any of the subjects," they said. If subsequent trials are passed, the vaccine could be ready by the end of the year.

archiveTopNews.title: More than a quarter of Victoria coronavirus patients not at home when doorknocked by ADF
archiveTopNews.summary: Door knocks carried out by authorities yesterday at 500 properties found that 1 in 4 coronavirus patients were not at home. Teams of Australian Defence Force (ADF) and Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) officers have been doorknocking all positive cases of coronavirus as the number of active infections has gone from "There will be a multitude of reasons for that but what I can confirm is more than 100 cases have been referred to Victoria Police," state Premier Daniel Andrews said.

archiveTopNews.title: Morrison and Andrews consider more restrictions to contain Victoria's escalating Covid-19 outbreak
archiveTopNews.summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison and Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews are planning to discuss whether further restrictions are necessary to contain the escalating outbreak in Victoria. Victoria recorded 723 new cases today (a record for the state), along with 13 new deaths. Andrews announced today that face coverings would be mandatory in all of Victoria. Previously the rule was restricted to metropolitan Melbourne and the Mitchell Shire.

archiveTopNews.title: Australian states tighten border restrictions as coronavirus community transmissions grow – as it happened
archiveTopNews.summary: Queensland announced today that its border will be closed to greater Sydney from 1am on Saturday. All aged care homes in Queensland are also closed to visitors for 48 hours.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria escalates response to aged care crisis as state records 384 new coronavirus cases
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria recorded 384 new cases overnight as well as six more deaths, taking the state's death toll to 83. State Premier Daniel Andrews has announced that more elective surgeries would be cancelled to free up resources to combat ballooning outbreaks within aged care facilities. Mr Andrews also added that health staff, particularly registered nurses, would be moved out of some hospitals and into aged care facilities.

archiveTopNews.title: Melbourne's public housing lockdown caused a 'massive' surge in calls to mental health helplines
archiveTopNews.summary: When the nine public housing towers in Melbourne went into lockdown, calls mental health organisations spiked by over 20 percent. "That is massive, we rarely register increases of that size," said Lifeline chair John Brogden. "In Victoria, calls to Beyond Blue’s support services doubled in the fortnight surrounding the re-introduction of lockdowns in Melbourne and Mitchell Shire," a spokesperson told SBS News.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria extends hotel stays for the homeless until April amid second coronavirus wave
archiveTopNews.summary: The Victorian announced a $150 million package to extend hotel stays for 2,000 homeless Victorians until at least April next year. During that time, efforts will be made to support these individuals into stable, long term housing.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorians must not go to work with coronavirus symptoms or lockdown 'will not end', Dan Andrews says
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria Premier Daniel Andrews has revealed that Victorians who go to work while displaying coronavirus symptoms are the "biggest driver of transmission" and added that the lockdown will not end until people instead get tested and isolate while waiting for results. Victoria recorded its highest daily increase in cases today with 532 people testing positive. Andrews warned all Victorians, no matter where they work, to "act on your symptoms, don't ignore them." "These are the facts and unless we see a change, then we're going to continue to see these numbers at unacceptably high levels," he added.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews gave an update on the state's coronavirus crisis. Here are some key takeaways
archiveTopNews.summary: 10 more individuals have died in Victoria due to the coronavirus and 42 remain in intensive care. The state also recorded 459 new cases overnight. State Premier Daniel Andrews mentioned that he is, "very proud to see so many people wearing masks right across the city, particularly in regional Victoria, too, where it's not compulsory,"

archiveTopNews.title: National cabinet commits to Covid-19 suppression strategy to secure zero community transmissions
archiveTopNews.summary: After a meeting on Friday, the national cabinet has agreed to share more data and COVID-19 testing response times, and have committed to a virus with a goal of having zero community transmissions. There is now acceptance in the national cabinet that all states and territories need to take precautions to avoid community transmission, currently only occurring in Victoria and New South Wales.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria records five deaths and 403 new cases of coronavirus overnight
archiveTopNews.summary: Three of the deaths are connected to aged care facilities. The five deaths bring the state's total death toll to 49.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorian coronavirus cases hit new record high with 484 cases, two more deaths
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria have broken a record with 484 new coronavirus cases announced. Victorian Premier, Daniel Andrews has said that he is, "very unhappy and very sad", aknowledging a report stating that report that nearly nine in 10 people did not isolate between the time they first felt sick and when they went to get a test. After testing, half of these people did not isolate while waiting for their test results. "Fifty-three per cent of people continuing to do their shopping, continuing to go to work continuing to do all sorts of things," he said. "Unless people who get tested are staying at home and isolating until they get their test results, then we will not see those numbers come down," he said before adding that the six week lockdown might be extended.

archiveTopNews.title: Jobkeeper and jobseeker payment: what do the changes mean for recipients?
archiveTopNews.summary: Jobkeeper has now been extended to 28 March 2021. The Jobkeeper rate will change after 27 Septmeber. It is currently at $1500 per employee per fortnight, but after 27 September, employees who ordinarily worked fewer than 20 hours a week will have reduced payments. Jobkeeper is also set to reduce payments over time. The coronavirus supplement for recipients of Jobseeker, will be cut from $550 per fortnight, to $250 per fortnight from 25 September onwards. The supplement will remain in place until 31 December.

archiveTopNews.title: New Tasmanian coronavirus case confirmed as young woman returning from Victoria
archiveTopNews.summary: Tasmania has recorded its first coronavirus cases in over 2 months. Before this, the state had recorded no active cases as of June 12th. The new case is a person that is currently in hotel quarantince since returning to Tasmania from Victoria. Tasmania Premier, Peter Gutwein has said that there were about 600 people in hotel quarantine in the state, and a further 1,000 in home quarantine.

archiveTopNews.title: Face masks will soon be mandatory in Melbourne. Here's what you need to know
archiveTopNews.summary: From 11.59pm on Wednesday, masks will be made compulsory for people who leave their homes in metropolitan Melbourne and the Mitchell Shire. Victorian Premier, Daniel Andrews has said that common sense will govern the new rules, advising that the measure must be done whenever it is practical to do so. He also advised that masks need not be hospital-grade masks, emphasizing, "any face covering is better than no face-covering."

archiveTopNews.link: Jobkeeper expected to be extended beyond September for businesses that ‘genuinely need it’
archiveTopNews.title: https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2020/jul/19/jobkeeper-expected-to-be-extended-beyond-september-for-businesses-that-genuinely-need-it
archiveTopNews.summary: The finance minister has said that there will be some adjustments to the Jobkeeper scheme. "The ultimate objective still has to be getting back into a situation where all businesses are in a position to pay for the wages of their employees out of their income," he said. The government will release an economic update on Thursday and outline the future of the jobseeker and jobkeeper payments. Until then, it is unclear how long the payments will be extended for.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria records three more coronavirus deaths and 217 new infections
archiveTopNews.summary: Mr Andrews said of the additional cases, 11 of them were linked to known outbreaks, and 205 of them are under investigation. 217 is a significant drop from the 428 cases registered on the previous day. The state's Chief Medical Officer, Dr Sutton said he was happy that case numbers had dropped, but also warned Victorians against complacency."It is a number that would have shocked us all a month ago, we need to remember it is still a high number," he said.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria records another 428 coronavirus cases and three more COVID-19 deaths
archiveTopNews.summary: The 428 new cases today represent the highest daily increase since the start of the pandemic, and three more people have died from the virus, taking the death toll in the state to 32. They were a man in his 70s, a man in his 80s and a woman in her 80s. Victorian Premier, Daniel Andrews has said that  the likelihood of a longer lockdown or heightened enforcement was "all in the hands" of every Victorian. "If we get a sense, and if the data continues to tell us … that the strategy is not being as effective as quickly as we would like, we may have to go to new rules," he said.

archiveTopNews.title: Black Lives Matter protests, a Covid-19 outbreak and the 'link' that didn't exist
archiveTopNews.summary: A number of news outlets had previously reported that authorities had confirmed a link between last month’s Melbourne Black Lives Matter protest and the Covid-19 breakout in public housing towers. The Victorian Department of Health and Human Services have now knocked down these claims. They said, "We are aware of six confirmed cases who attended the Black Lives Matter protest," adding "Currently there is no evidence to suggest they acquired the virus from the protest, and "None of these cases are known to reside at a major public housing complex. Currently no known nor suspected episodes of transmission occurred at the protest itself."

archiveTopNews.title: New coronavirus case confirmed as SA announces fines for travellers who refuse tests
archiveTopNews.summary: The South Australian Government has announced fines of $1,000 for travellers from Victoria who refuse a coronavirus test on arrival in SA, as the state confirms its first COVID-19 case in more than two weeks. Mr Marshall last week announced coronavirus testing for everyone crossing the border from Victoria within 24 hours of their arrival, and again on day 12 of their quarantine. But today he said the tests would be mandatory, and that anyone who did not comply with that requirement would be subject to a $1,000 on-the-spot fine.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorian coronavirus case increase hits record high with two new deaths, but no stage four restrictions yet
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria has recorded 317 new coronavirus cases overnight, the biggest daily increase since the pandemic began, and another two men in their 80s have died from the virus. In announcing the figures, Premier Daniel Andrews said it was "way too early" for the state to be moving to a new stage of restrictions. Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton said Victoria may not yet have hit the peak of its latest surge in cases. Professor Sutton said the virus had an average incubation period of about five or six days, which meant case numbers would not start to plateau for another few days.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison says Australia cannot shut down to contain second wave of Covid-19
archiveTopNews.summary: Scott Morrison says the response to a second wave of Covid-19 infections cannot be shutting the country down to try to eliminate the virus, and he’s moved to reassure people his government will not be withdrawing income support "for those in need". With renewed debate around whether Australia should respond to the latest outbreak and a spike in community transmission with more forceful lockdowns, Morrison said on Wednesday elimination was impractical, but Victoria’s chief health officer Brett Sutton told reporters it was an idea "worthy of consideration". With Victoria reporting another 238 cases of the illness, and another fatality, Sutton said he would "love" elimination, but now wasn’t the time to make "a detailed examination about its feasibility". He said any shift in the public health strategy would require consideration by chief medical officers and leaders through the national cabinet.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria records 238 new coronavirus cases as Daniel Andrews warns of more restrictions
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria announced one new coronavirus death and 238 fresh cases on Wednesday, the fifth day in a row of more than 200 new infections. Premier Daniel Andrews confirmed on Wednesday morning a woman in her 90s had died overnight, bringing the total number of deaths in the state to 27. Of the new cases, Mr Andrews said 29 were related to known outbreaks and 209 were under investigation. Amid speculation the government is considering a move to a 'Stage 4' lockdown, Mr Andrews warned that if the current rules are not followed "we will have to move to additional restrictions".

archiveTopNews.title: WA records eight new coronavirus cases amid calls for restrictions on interstate travellers
archiveTopNews.summary: WA recorded eight new cases of coronavirus overnight — the largest daily increase since May 29 when the state was dealing with an outbreak on the Al Kuwait live export ship. All of the new cases are overseas travellers who are in hotel quarantine, bringing the state's total to 644, with 29 active cases. It comes as the WA Government faces growing pressure to further lock down its border and tighten restrictions on people wanting to enter the state, as airline passengers from Victoria face the first day of mandatory COVID tests on arrival at Perth Airport. WA Cabinet minister Simone McGurk said the Government was continuing to monitor the coronavirus situation in New South Wales and was considering whether to impose similar measures on travellers from that state.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia records two new coronavirus deaths as confirmed infections surge past 10,000
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria has recorded another 270 coronavirus cases as the total number of infections recorded within Australia passes the grim milestone of 10,000. Two more people have also died of the virus in Victoria, a man and woman who were both in their 80s, taking the national death toll to 110. The number of new cases in Victoria was a significant increase on the 177 recorded on Monday and is the fourth day in the past five of more than 200 cases. Deputy Chief Medical Officer Michael Kidd on Tuesday said the country had passed "another national milestone", with at least 10,251 coronavirus infections recorded in Australia since the pandemic began.

archiveTopNews.title: Queensland declares NSW towns of Campbelltown and Liverpool coronavirus hotspots
archiveTopNews.summary: Queensland Health has declared coronavirus hotspots in several areas of New South Wales after a cluster of cases in Sydney. Any non-Queensland residents who have visited, or visit, the Campbelltown and Liverpool city areas will not be allowed entry into Queensland from midday today. It follows a cluster of 28 cases connected to the Crossroads Hotel on the Hume Highway in south-west Sydney. Queenslanders who have been to the hotspots, or travel there in the future, will be forced into hotel quarantine when re-entering the state, at their own cost.

archiveTopNews.title: Government faces tough questions over CovidSafe app as outbreaks emerge in Victoria and NSW
archiveTopNews.summary: The CovidSafe contact tracing app was much hyped by the federal government and touted as a crucial tool that would keep Australians safe while coronavirus lockdowns were lifted. Now, with a surge in cases in Victoria leading to the lockdown of millions in metropolitan Melbourne, as well as an uptick in the number of cases in New South Wales, questions are being asked of the app. Labor leader Anthony Albanese on Tuesday labelled the app a "dud".

archiveTopNews.title: Advice on using face masks during the coronavirus pandemic has changed — here's what you need to know
archiveTopNews.summary: Australian health experts have not been recommending healthy people wear face masks and have warned wearing them incorrectly can put us at risk during the pandemic. That messaging changed in Victoria on Saturday when Premier Daniel Andrews said masks would not be made mandatory, but people in his state's locked-down areas should wear them when they could not maintain physical distancing. This article addresses common questions about face masks.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria records 177 new coronavirus cases in 'good sign' Melbourne lockdown is working
archiveTopNews.summary: The 177 cases confirmed on Monday marks the first time since Thursday the number of new infections has dropped below 200 in Victoria. Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton said Monday's numbers were a "good sign" but would like to see a longer trend of decreasing case numbers. "It's great it's lower than our peak. But it may not be our peak yet," he said. Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews said all Victorians need to take COVID-19 seriously. Mr Andrews said it's possible the lockdown could be extended beyond metropolitan Melbourne and Mitchell Shire.

archiveTopNews.title: Return to remote learning in Victoria amid new coronavirus death and 273 fresh cases
archiveTopNews.summary: More than 700,000 students will return to online learning in Victoria after the state reported a week of triple-digit daily increases in cases. Prep to year 10 students in locked-down parts of Victoria will return to online learning for Term 3. Premier Andrews on Sunday confirmed students in metropolitan Melbourne and Mitchell Shire, north of the city, will learn from home from 20 July until at least 19 August. Onsite learning will be available for students whose parents cannot work from home and for students with special needs who attend mainstream schools.

archiveTopNews.title: Queensland COVID-19 human vaccine trial 'very encouraging'
archiveTopNews.summary: A COVID-19 vaccine developed by the University of Queensland is now ready to be tested on humans, giving hope of a breakthrough in combating the virus that has caused a worldwide pandemic. The human testing of the "molecular clamp" vaccine candidate, to start on Monday, follows encouraging results from animal testing trials conducted in the Netherlands, the Sunday Mail in Brisbane reports. Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk praised UQ for their search for a COVID-19 vaccine and said she expected the university to reveal more on Monday.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria records another 216 coronavirus cases as 'kind soul' dies with COVID-19
archiveTopNews.summary: A man remembered by his family as a "kind soul" has died with COVID-19 in a Victorian hospital, with the state recording another 216 cases of coronavirus. Only 30 of the new infections were connected to contained outbreaks and 186 were under investigation. Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton said the state had about 100 separate outbreaks for health officials to contend with. There are now at least 1,249 active cases in Victoria.

archiveTopNews.title: Melburnians urged to wear masks as Victoria records 288 new coronavirus cases
archiveTopNews.summary: Victorians have been urged to wear masks when they leave their homes after the state recorded 288 COVID-19 cases in 24 hours, the largest daily increase of the pandemic so far. Premier Daniel Andrews said masks were not being made mandatory, but people in lockdown areas should wear masks in situations where they cannot maintain physical distancing. He said the Government would order 2 million reusable masks for community distribution, and boost local manufacturing capabilities.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorian Government announces $534 million support package for businesses hit by coronavirus lockdown
archiveTopNews.summary: The Victorian Government has announced a $534 million support package for businesses impacted by the coronavirus lockdown. The package includes: a $30 million fund for hospitality businesses; a $26 million mental health support package for small business; a $40 million fund to help regional tourism businesses to cover refunds and marketing; $20 million for small businesses in Melbourne's CBD; and $5,000 grants to be made available for 80,000 eligible businesses in metropolitan Melbourne and the Mitchell Shire. Treasurer Tim Pallas said the state's unemployment rate could peak at 11 per cent and gross state product could decline by about 14 per cent relative to pre-pandemic forecasts.

archiveTopNews.title: Record calls to mental health services during second lockdown
archiveTopNews.summary: Victorians are reaching out to mental health services for support in record numbers as Melbourne enters a second coronavirus lockdown. Lifeline is reporting a 22 per cent surge in calls in Victoria since Sunday compared with the same time last year, while calls from Victoria to Beyond Blue’s support services have doubled in the past fortnight. Lifeline Australia chairman John Brogden said the service had received almost 90,000 calls a month since March, which amounted to a call every 30 seconds. This was a sign the strict lockdown measures were taking a toll on the mental health of Victorians, he said.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus crisis: WA Premier Mark McGowan announces phase five start pushed back from July 18 to August 1
archiveTopNews.summary: Mark McGowan says WA’s hard border with the rest of the nation will be up for “as long as it takes” amid news phase five of WA’s COVID-19 restrictions will be delayed until August 1. The Premier said border measures between WA and Victoria could be tightened even further yet and WA Police Commissioner Chris Dawson flagged stopping all planes from Victoria from coming into WA as being an option to keep COVID-19 out of the state. It comes amid news from the Premier that the start of WA’s next phase of restrictions had been pushed back two weeks. The Premier said WA had decided to be extra cautious in delaying restriction relaxations because of the situation in Victoria.

archiveTopNews.title: Restrictions to ease in eight of Melbourne's locked-down public housing towers
archiveTopNews.summary: A hard lockdown is set to end for eight of the public housing estates in Melbourne on Saturday, meaning people will be able to leave for essential purposes. All towers, except the 33 Alfred Street estate, will move to Stage 3 restrictions, in line with the rest of metropolitan Melbourne. This means residents will be able to leave for essential work, study, exercise or care responsibilities. Tenants in the Alfred Street building, where there have been 53 cases of COVID-19, will have to remain inside for another nine days. However, they will be allowed to have supervised exercise outside.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW-Victoria border control to be in place for at least six weeks as Queensland and SA clamp down
archiveTopNews.summary: Border controls between Victoria and New South Wales will remain in place for at least six weeks, while Queensland will turn Victorians away at the border and South Australia will require those permitted into the state to wear face masks. Meanwhile, Tasmania has extended its state of emergency until 31 August, in response to the Melbourne outbreak, but will consider reopening its borders to other states.

archiveTopNews.title: Josh Frydenberg says Coalition will extend income support and may bring forward tax cuts
archiveTopNews.summary: The Morrison government is considering bringing forward income tax cuts and will extend income support beyond September, the treasurer, Josh Frydenberg, has said. Frydenberg and the prime minister, Scott Morrison, have been increasingly frank about the need for the extension of economic supports as Victoria re-enters a six-week lockdown to fight the spread of Covid-19. Although the income tax cut proposal is yet to go to cabinet and the government’s decision on extending the $70bn jobkeeper program will not be announced until 23 July, Victorian businesses are requesting an extra two months of wage subsidies citing the new lockdown. It comes as banks have announced they will extend the six-month suspension of loan repayments by a further four months for business loan and mortgage customers who are still experiencing financial hardship.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW-Victoria coronavirus breach after Melbourne Jetstar flight lands in Sydney where passengers aren't screened for COVID-19
archiveTopNews.summary: Passengers on a flight from Melbourne to Sydney last night disembarked without being screened by NSW Health officials, in a major breach of the state's coronavirus protocols. An email from Sydney Airport leaked to the ABC claims Jetstar breached NSW Government health orders by allowing travellers on flight JQ520, which landed at 6:53pm, to get off without being checked. Federal Health Minister Greg Hunt said his department would seek answers from the Victorian and New South Wales governments.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia set to cap international flights to contain spike in coronavirus cases
archiveTopNews.summary: Australia will reduce the number of international flights entering the country to ease pressure on hotel quarantine amid Melbourne's coronavirus outbreak. Prime Minister Scott Morrison will unveil a plan to cut the number of international flights at Friday's national cabinet meeting with state premiers. "In Victoria, we have suspended those flights coming in and that has meant that people have moved on to other flights going into other capitals,"he told reporters in Canberra on Wednesday.

archiveTopNews.title: Metropolitan Melbourne put into six-week lockdown after surge of 191 new coronavirus infections
archiveTopNews.summary: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews says metropolitan Melbourne will be put into a six-week lockdown after recording 191 new coronavirus infections on Tuesday. The lockdown, which will also apply to the Mitchell Shire north of the city, will take effect from 11.59pm on Wednesday. Mr Andrews told reporters on Tuesday new infections would quickly spiral out of control if drastic suppression measures weren't put in place.

archiveTopNews.title: Queensland joins WA in push for international flight cap amid Melbourne virus spike
archiveTopNews.summary: Queensland and Western Australia have urged the federal government to cap international flights arriving in Australia to ease pressure on hotel quarantine. State premiers have raised concerns with Prime Minister Scott Morrison as Victoria struggles with a concerning coronavirus infection spike. Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk said extreme caution should be applied when dealing with arrivals from overseas. WA Premier Mark McGowan wants a cap of about one international flight every three days landing in Perth.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria-NSW border to close for the first time in 100 years as Melbourne coronavirus cases hit record daily high
archiveTopNews.summary: The border between New South Wales and Victoria will close at 11:59 on Tuesday night as coronavirus cases continue to surge in Victoria. Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews confirmed the decision on Monday morning as the state recorded another 127 coronavirus cases overnight, a record daily increase for the state. The border closure decision was made in consultation with Prime Minister Scott Morrison and NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian, Mr Andrews said. The decision marks the first time the Victoria-NSW border has been shut in 100 years - officials last blocked movement between the two states in 1919 during the Spanish flu pandemic.

archiveTopNews.title: WA pushes for cap on international flights to reduce coronavirus risk
archiveTopNews.summary: WA Premier Mark McGowan has sought Commonwealth approval to cap the number of international flights landing in Perth. Mr McGowan said he had requested international arrivals be limited to "something in the vicinity of one flight per three days". He said WA continued to lead the country as a "safe haven" from COVID-19, and the state had not recorded a case of community infection since April 11. Mr McGowan said there had recently been an uptick in domestic and international arrivals at Perth Airport. He said Cabinet had today approved the drafting of legislation to force any returning travellers to pay for a compulsory 14 days of quarantine.

archiveTopNews.title: 'Play it safe': AMA calls for a nationwide freeze on lifting COVID restrictions
archiveTopNews.summary: The Australian Medical Association's President, Tony Bartone has urged states to temporarily cease the lifting of restrictions. This is in response to 108 new cases in Victoria on Saturday. Dr Bartone said it was disappointing that the problem's in Melbourne's hotspots were linked to failures to follow "established and successful" public health guidelines.

archiveTopNews.title: A group of 3,000 Melburnians have been locked down in public housing towers. But how will authorities manage it?
archiveTopNews.summary: Authorities have placed over 3000 residents across nine public housing towers in lockdown. Premier Daniel Andrews has urged residents to to view these measures as protective rather than as a punishment. Many Victorians have rallied behind the affected residents, including a crowdfunding campaign for residents, organised by the Victorian Trades Hall Council, that has raised over $250,000 so far.

archiveTopNews.title: Cap on international arrivals introduced at Sydney Airport to ease coronavirus quarantine demands
archiveTopNews.summary: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has warned that international flights to Sydney over the coming weeks will be subject to a cap on arrivals and flights could be cancelled. At the request of the NSW Government, new Federal Government limits will be introduced from midnight tonight. NSW Health said overseas arrivals will be capped at 450 passengers a day, with a maximum of 50 passengers allowed per incoming flight. The move is aimed at easing pressure on hotel quarantine capacity.

archiveTopNews.title: More suburbs in lockdown as Victoria records 108 new coronavirus cases
archiveTopNews.summary: More suburbs in Melbourne's inner-north will be placed in lockdown and thousands of residents in nine public housing towers will be confined to their homes after Victoria recorded 108 new coronavirus cases. The suburbs of Kensington, Flemington and North Melbourne, in postcodes 3031 and 3051, will join 36 others where stage three coronavirus restrictions apply, meaning residents can only leave their homes for four reasons: food or essential supplies; medical care or care giving; exercise; or for work or education. The lockdown will take effect from 11.59pm on Saturday. A large coronavirus cluster has emerged in the Flemington and North Melbourne public housing estates where residents will be placed in a "hard lockdown" for at least five days, "effective immediately".

archiveTopNews.title: More than 10,000 Victorians refused coronavirus tests
archiveTopNews.summary: More than 10,000 people have refused to be tested for coronavirus in Melbourne's hotspot suburbs as 66 new cases across the state were confirmed. Health Minister Jenny Mikakos labelled the refusal as "disappointing" and urged residents to get tested as she speculated the mass coronavirus outbreak in Victoria could be linked to a "super spreader". "There seems to be a single source of infection for many of the cases that have gone across the northern and western suburbs of Melbourne," Ms Mikakos said. The health minister said the government is investigating the reasons behind the mass refusal of testing, but reassured the community that 24,000 tests had been undertaken yesterday.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria records 77 new coronavirus cases and jump in community transmission of COVID-19
archiveTopNews.summary: Another 77 people in Victoria have been diagnosed with coronavirus and the state has recorded its single biggest increase in community transmission to date. Of the 77 new cases, 13 are linked to outbreaks, 37 were discovered through routine testing and 27 are still under investigation. Community transmission cases, where the source of the infection cannot be traced, are up by 31. Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton says "there is absolutely a possibility, an expectation" that more people will die. He says there is evidence of student-to-student and teacher-to-teacher transmission in schools, but still expects students will return to classrooms after school holidays.

archiveTopNews.title: Melbourne coronavirus scare as NSW man who tested positive returned to work at Sydney Woolworths
archiveTopNews.summary: A Sydney man who spent two weeks in hotel quarantine in Victoria has tested positive for coronavirus after returning to NSW, sparking a crisis at the Woolworths he worked at. The store in Balmain, in Sydney's inner-west, has told 50 staff to self-isolate, and NSW Health Minister Brad Hazzard warned anyone who had been to the supermarket to be "alert". NSW chief health officer Kerry Chant said the man worked in the self-service section of the grocery store and was considered to pose a low level of infection risk. The man had recently returned from Bangladesh and had been quarantining in a Melbourne hotel, where he was deemed not to be infectious despite returning a positive test there.

archiveTopNews.title: As NSW coronavirus restrictions ease further, here's what has changed from today
archiveTopNews.summary: Today brings a raft of eased NSW coronavirus restrictions right in time for school holidays, but the winter break is going to look a little different this year. From today, indoor venues including pubs, cafes and restaurants, as well as functions, can hold any number of people, as long as they remain seated and stick to one person per four square metres. This also includes weddings, which were previously subjected to separate limitations and capped at 20 guests. A maximum of 10,000 fans are allowed to fill stadiums for sporting or cultural events from today, while community sport can resume for kids and adults alike. The State Government has increased the capacity of public transport services from today, allowing 68 passengers on a train and 23 on a bus — double the cap implemented in May.

archiveTopNews.title: People refusing to get tested in Melbourne's hotspot suburbs could face fines, Scott Morrison warns
archiveTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has raised the prospect of fines for people refusing to get coronavirus tests as Melbourne grapples with an outbreak, but Premier Daniel Andrews says people will not be forced to take tests. Scott Morrison has thrown his support behind the Victorian government's tough suburban lockdowns designed to save Melbourne from coronavirus. The prime minister has also warned people who refuse to be checked for the disease could face fines as a hotspot testing blitz continues. But Mr Andrews said Victorians will not be forced into taking tests in the lockdown areas because it would be logistically difficult and only possible if police accompanied testing staff door to door.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorian hotspot residents will be banned from NSW and fined $11,000 if they try to enter state
archiveTopNews.summary: Melbourne residents of COVID-19 outbreak areas who seek to enter NSW could from Thursday face six months' imprisonment or a fine of $11,000. NSW residents who return from Melbourne hotspot areas, meanwhile, will be required to self-isolate at home for 14 days. People trying to enter NSW stadiums from Wednesday may be required to show their driver's licence to prove they're not from Victoria.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria reimposes 'stay-at-home' orders on coronavirus hotspots for four weeks
archiveTopNews.summary: Victorians living in suburbs at the centre of fresh coronavirus outbreaks will only be allowed to leave their house for essential activities from Wednesday night. Premier Daniel Andrews on Tuesday announced stay-at-home orders would be reimposed on coronavirus hotspots after a 14th-straight day of double-digit growth in new cases. Under the restrictions, people can only leave their homes for four reasons: to exercise, go to school or work, undertake care responsibilities, and buy food and other essentials. The lockdown applies to 10 postcodes in western and northern Melbourne and could affect more than 300,000 people.

archiveTopNews.title: South Australia scraps plan to lift border restrictions on 20 July amid Victoria coronavirus spike
archiveTopNews.summary: South Australia has scrapped a plan to lift all its remaining border restrictions next month amid the spike in coronavirus cases in Victoria. Premier Steven Marshall says the 20 July date to lift quarantine measures for Victoria, NSW and the ACT has been abandoned on the latest health advice. He says the state may move separately on NSW and the ACT but can't make any move in relation to Victoria in the current circumstances.

archiveTopNews.title: Queensland will reopen its borders on July 10, but not to Victorians
archiveTopNews.summary: Queensland will reopen its borders on July 10, but travel from Victoria will remain restricted. Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk said anyone who had travelled from Victoria, including Queensland residents, would be prevented from entering the state unless they quarantined at a hotel at their own expense.  From midnight on Friday anyone entering Queensland from Victoria will have to pay for their own hotel quarantine. The only people who will be exempt from mandatory quarantine are essential workers, meaning residents who have travelled south for compassionate reasons will have to cough up $200 for each day of their fortnight's stay.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria records 75 new coronavirus cases as authorities warn 'it will get worse before it gets better'
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria has recorded 75 new coronavirus infections, bringing the state's confirmed total to 2099 cases. It is the state's fourth-highest daily total since the start of the pandemic. The state has recorded cases in the double-digits for 13 days in a row. Victorian Chief Medical Officer Brett Sutton called the new numbers "absolutely concerning". "I think it will get worse before it gets better," he said on Monday. Mr Sutton left the door open to suburban lockdowns.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria introduces mandatory coronavirus testing for travellers, flags Melbourne lockdowns after recording 49 new cases
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria, which has recorded new coronavirus cases in the double-digits for 12 days in a row, announced 49 new infections on Sunday. Victoria's fight against COVID-19 has intensified with the decision to implement mandatory testing for returned travellers before they are allowed out of quarantine in hotels. The government says people in quarantine will be tested twice - first on day three of the 14-day quarantine period and then again on day 11. Premier Daniel Andrews also said the state will consider potential stay-at-home orders and suburban lockdowns to keep on top of clusters in Melbourne, after 49 cases new cases were confirmed on Sunday.

archiveTopNews.title: Reports JobSeeker will rise by $75 a week 'factually incorrect', Social Services Minister says
archiveTopNews.summary: Reports that the JobSeeker unemployment payment will rise by $75 a week after September are "factually incorrect", Social Services Minister Anne Ruston says. As part of its coronavirus assistance the Government temporarily increased the payment — formerly known as Newstart — to $1,100 a fortnight. It is due to revert back to $565 at the end of September, when the JobKeeper payments also end. But News Corp is reporting the payment will be permanently boosted to $715 a fortnight and that the $75 a week increase was the preferred option of some cabinet ministers. Senator Ruston said the report was "factually incorrect".

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus Australia: Victoria reports jump of 41 cases and sends emergency alerts to hotspots
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria has reported another Covid-19 jump with 41 new cases reported on Saturday as the Australian state was experiencing a potential second wave of the virus. Victoria’s deputy chief health officer, Dr Annaliese van Diemen, said the state had tested almost 22,000 people across several outbreak clusters in the previous 24 hours. Emergency alerts were being sent out to residents in the hotspot Melbourne suburbs of Keilor Downs and Broadmeadows, encouraging them to get tested.

archiveTopNews.title: WA enters stage four of easing coronavirus restrictions
archiveTopNews.summary: Western Australia's Premier Mark McGowan has praised local residents for their behaviour as the state entered phase four easing of restrictions early this morning. Mr McGowan said WA was "very fortunate" to be leading the nation – and the world – in reopening its economy thanks to a low rate of infection and a hard border closure. The premier said many businesses in WA can get back to a "virtual normal" of operating, saving thousands of jobs in the process.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison says 'not unreasonable' for Australia’s borders to remain shut until mid-next year
archiveTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has added to a growing belief that Australia’s borders won’t reopen this year, saying it was “not unreasonable” to believe international travel will not resume until mid-to-late 2021 at the earliest. Aside from a potential travel bubble with New Zealand, Australia is widely expected to keep its borders shut from the rest of the world - potentially until a vaccine or treatment to the coronavirus is found. On Thursday, Qantas CEO Alan Joyce expressed doubts international flights with his airline would be able to restart prior to July next year, as he announced 6,000 jobs will be axed as a result of a major downturn due to the virus.

archiveTopNews.title: All travellers returning to Australia will be tested for coronavirus before and after quarantine
archiveTopNews.summary: Chief Medical Officer Brendan Murphy announced Australia's new testing regime following a national cabinet meeting on Friday. All travellers returning to Australia will be tested for coronavirus as they enter quarantine and before they're allowed to leave, as the government beefs up measures to prevent further outbreaks. Chief Medical Officer Brendan Murphy announced Australia's new testing regime following a national cabinet meeting on Friday.

archiveTopNews.title: Nationwide toilet paper limits introduced as new coronavirus outbreaks spark panic-buying
archiveTopNews.summary: An outbreak of fresh cases of COVID-19 across Victoria has triggered a resumption of panic buying, with some supermarket shelves again cleared of toilet paper, pasta and milk. Coles and Woolworths have reintroduced nationwide buying limits on toilet paper and paper towel in a bid to ward off a resurgence of coronavirus-related panic buying. The supermarket giants had already placed restrictions on buying from its Victorian stores as the state battles a fresh outbreak of COVID-19. On Friday, Coles announced customers across Australia would only be able to buy one pack of toilet paper and paper towels per shopper, and two packs of flour, sugar, pasta and rice.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria records 33 new coronavirus cases, Daniel Andrews declares 'testing blitz'
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria has recorded another 33 coronavirus cases, as the defence force is brought in to bolster efforts to stop the spread of COVID-19. The premier announced a 'testing blitz' in Melbourne's suburbs with the highest number of community transmission cases, Keilor Downs and Broadmeadows, with the blitz to then extend to other suburbs Maidstone, Albanvale, Sunshine West, Hallam, Brunswick West, Fawkner, Reservoir, and Pakenham. NSW Health Minister Brad Hazzard on Thursday called on Melbourne residents from the COVID hot spots to refrain from attending major events in NSW including AFL and NRL games until the recent spike in COVID-19 cases ends.

archiveTopNews.title: Qantas to cut 6,000 jobs, slash costs as part of coronavirus recovery plan
archiveTopNews.summary: Qantas says it will cut at least 6,000 jobs across all parts of the business and continue to stand down 15,000 employees as part of its plan to recover from the impact of the COVID pandemic. Australia's flag carrier also said it will ground at least 100 aircraft for up to 12 months and reduce $15 billion in costs over the next three years. Qantas' domestic capacity is currently running at about 15 per cent of its pre-coronavirus levels, following an easing in social and travel restrictions. The majority of staff stood down are associated with the airline’s international services. CEO Alan Joyce estimates close to $600 million will be spent on redundancies.

archiveTopNews.title: As Victoria's coronavirus restrictions tighten, here's what you can and can't do across Australia
archiveTopNews.summary: As Australia's coronavirus recovery continues, different circumstances in each state and territory mean the country is no longer opening up in unison. On Tuesday, Victoria recorded double-digit growth in new cases for the seventh day in a row. While in South Australia, which has gone several weeks without a new case, authorities are preparing to move to the next stage of easing restrictions. So what's happening in each state and territory? Based on information from 23 June, this is the state of play.

archiveTopNews.title: Man dies from coronavirus in Victoria as state records 20 new cases
archiveTopNews.summary: A man in his 80s has died of coronavirus in Victoria, as the state records 20 new cases. The man is the 20th person to succumb to the virus in the state and the first death in Australia in a month, taking the national toll to 103. The steady increase in new cases prompted the state government to pause easing of restrictions and to name six local government areas as coronavirus hotspots: Brimbank, Casey, Cardinia, Darebin, Hume and Moreland.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria's coronavirus cases rise by 17 as two schools in Melbourne's hotspots close
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria has recorded its seventh consecutive day of double-digit increases in coronavirus cases, and two primary schools in COVID-19 hotspots have been closed following student infections. Students from Brunswick East Primary School and Keilor Views Primary School are among the latest cases. Premier Daniel Andrews said "very deep engagement with multicultural communities" began yesterday to make sure people in six COVID-19 hotspots knew the current health advice. Mr Andrews also said testing may be offered to people without symptoms in the areas with the highest levels of virus transmission

archiveTopNews.title: Turn away people from COVID-19 hotspots, NSW Premier tells businesses
archiveTopNews.summary: NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian is calling on tourism operators and other businesses to shun customers from Melbourne’s coronavirus hotspots as the number of active cases in Victoria continues to rise. However, Ms Berejiklian refused to bow to growing calls to close the southern border, particularly in the lead-up to the school holidays. On Monday, NSW Deputy Premier John Barilaro said ski resorts would want border closures ahead of the school holidays in order to prevent outbreaks in the state. But Ms Berejiklian, who has been consistently opposed to border closures, instead called on businesses to shun customers from Melbourne.

archiveTopNews.title: Anxious Melbourne residents forced to drive in circles as they wait for Covid-19 test
archiveTopNews.summary: Many Melbournians attempting to get tested for Covid-19 have faced another day of long waits, with some forced to drive in loops for up to an hour while awaiting treatment. Victoria is expanding its Covid-19 response in six local government areas with high levels of community transmission, urging all residents with even mild symptoms to present for testing. On Tuesday the premier, Daniel Andrews, said the recent cases were “certain” to result in further community transmission. On Tuesday lines of cars stretched down the street at some locations as people responded to the call to get tested. On Monday callers to talkback radio reported three-hour waits at drive-through clinics around the city, suggesting the Northland shopping centre clinic even had to turn people away.

archiveTopNews.title: WA's coronavirus restrictions are being significantly eased under phase four. Here's what it means for you
archiveTopNews.summary: Crowds of 30,000 at football games and drinking beers standing up are among the freedoms West Australians can enjoy from this Saturday, when the state enters Phase 4 of eased coronavirus restrictions. From 11:59pm on June 26, WA will do away with its limits on public gatherings, which are currently capped at up to 300 people, depending on the setting. The limit on people allowed into venues will now be dictated by the state's unique two-square-metre rule, requiring at least two square metres of floor space be afforded per patron. More details on the specific restrictions lifted can be found in the article below.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus cases in Victoria rise by 19 as state of emergency extended for a further four weeks
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria has recorded 19 new coronavirus cases overnight, the fifth day in a row of double-digit increases, prompting the Government to extend the state of emergency for a further four weeks. Ms Mikakos said the state of emergency had been extended to allow the Chief Health Officer to continue to issue fresh legal directions. The recent spike in cases has prompted the Government to bring back some tougher restrictions, including limiting visitors inside homes to five people and outdoor gatherings to 10 people from midnight tonight. But some restrictions will still be relaxed, including allowing gyms to reopen from tomorrow.

archiveTopNews.title: Queensland Government loosens coronavirus restrictions, allowing more fans in sport stadiums
archiveTopNews.summary: The cheering in Queensland stadiums will be a little louder from next weekend, as the State Government further loosens coronavirus restrictions. Speaking on the pitch at Lang Park, Health Minister Steven Miles said up to 10,000 fans would be allowed in time for Saturday's clash between the Brisbane Broncos and the Gold Coast Titans. "Beginning next weekend, our stadiums will be allowed to have up to 25 per cent of their usual crowd capacity, up to that cap of 10,000 that was set by the Prime Minister and National Cabinet," Mr Miles said.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorian coronavirus restrictions tightening as cases continue to increase
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria will bring back tougher coronavirus restrictions, limiting gatherings in homes to five people from Monday, in a bid to address a recent increase in case numbers. Premier Daniel Andrews said today's case numbers were the highest they had been in two months, with 25 new cases identified overnight. Of those, just one was a returned traveller in hotel quarantine, while 14 were linked to existing outbreaks, six were discovered in routine testing and four are under investigation.

archiveTopNews.title: Plans to lift South Australia's remaining coronavirus border restrictions could be pushed back after spike in Victoria
archiveTopNews.summary: Plans to lift South Australia's remaining border restrictions by July 20 could be pushed back, after Victoria reported its highest number of coronavirus cases in two months. Health Minister Stephen Wade said the health and wellbeing of South Australians was the State Government's priority in setting a timeline to reopen the state. His comments came after Victoria announced 25 new cases overnight, including 14 linked to existing outbreaks and one returned traveller in hotel quarantine.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus restrictions to ease despite fears of second wave 'tipping point'
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria will forge ahead with loosening coronavirus restrictions on Monday as experts worry the state could be at the "tipping point" of a second wave of infections. Thirteen new COVID-19 cases were reported in Victoria on Friday - the third successive day with a double-digit rise. Professor James McCaw, an epidemiologist with the Doherty Institute who has worked on government modelling during the pandemic, said it was fair to ask whether Victoria should be loosening the rules on June 22.

archiveTopNews.title: The Northern Territory will open its borders to interstate travellers on 17 July
archiveTopNews.summary: The Northern Territory will reopen its borders to interstate travellers on July 17, nearly four months after they were closed due to the coronavirus pandemic. Thursday marked 28 days since the last of the 30 people to have COVID-19 in the Territory recovered, a period of time NT Chief Health Officer Hugh Heggie had recommended as it represented two 14-day incubation periods of the virus. From 12.01am on July 17, people who enter the Territory from other states will no longer have to go into quarantine. It also means Territorians will be able to travel to the rest of Australia to see friends and family without having to serve 14 days' quarantine on their return.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus cases in Victoria rise by 18
archiveTopNews.summary: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews says the state will press on with its plans to further ease coronavirus restrictions next week, despite an apparent increase in community transmission of COVID-19. The state has recorded a further 18 new cases, including a third Black Lives Matter protester and a "very young child" who attended a childcare centre while infectious. Mr Andrews said health officials believed the state could continue to "slowly, cautiously, safely" reopen, but reminded people to adhere to social distancing measures.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus: Greg Hunt says Australia is an island sanctuary as global pandemic grows and international travel ruled out
archiveTopNews.summary: Health Minister Greg Hunt has stressed international travel probably won't resume until next year as the global COVID-19 pandemic continues but says Australia is an "island sanctuary". Mr Hunt told Today global infections are growing at a concerning rate and this rules out overseas travel for Australians. The only possibility of overseas travel for Australians now rests on bilateral agreements or a COVID-19 vaccine.

archiveTopNews.title: Australian arts support package expected after talks with Scott Morrison
archiveTopNews.summary: The expenditure review committee of cabinet is expected to sign off on a support package for the struggling arts and entertainment industry on Thursday night after talks between Scott Morrison and representatives from the entertainment sector. The support under consideration includes assistance with startup costs to help artists resume touring as public health restrictions ease, and a dedicated grants fund to help entertainment businesses replenish their capital after the economic devastation created by Covid-19.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia's Covidsafe coronavirus tracing app works as few as one in four times for some devices
archiveTopNews.summary: The federal government’s Covidsafe contact tracing app works as few as one in every four times for some devices, documents tabled in the Senate have revealed. The evidence for the first time shows the true state of the operation of the app, despite continuous claims from the government services minister, Stuart Robert, and the Digital Transformation Agency over the past two months that the app "works".

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria records 21 new coronavirus cases in the biggest spike since early May
archiveTopNews.summary: Returned travellers in hotel quarantine have given Victoria its biggest spike in daily coronavirus cases in more than a month. Health Minister Jenny Mikakos on Wednesday announced the state's infection tally had increased to 1762 after 21 new cases were recorded. The last time a bigger increase was recorded was on May 4, when 22 cases were identified amid the Cedar Meats outbreak crisis.

archiveTopNews.title: South Australia is opening its borders to Tasmania, WA and the NT
archiveTopNews.summary: South Australia is lifting some COVID-19 border restrictions allowing people to travel from Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Tasmania from midnight on Tuesday. Premier Steven Marshall says the change means people from those states will no longer be required to stay in quarantine for 14 days when they arrive in SA. He says people who recently arrived from those states and are in isolation, are also free to move into the wider community. At this stage border restrictions related to NSW, Queensland and Victoria will be lifted on July 20.

archiveTopNews.title: 12 New Cases in Victoria including 7 from a family outbreak in Coburg, and 1 BLM protest attendee
archiveTopNews.summary: The 7 new cases bring the total number of cases from the Coburg cluster to 11. A second person who attended Melbourne's Black Lives Matter protest has also tested positive for COVID-19. Victoria's Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton said the Black Lives Matter protester was a young woman who attended the demonstration in Melbourne on June 6, but was very unlikely to have acquired the virus there. Professor Sutton said the woman wore personal protective equipment (PPE) at the protest and was unlikely to have transmitted the virus to other attendees because she had been minimally symptomatic at the time. The individual is also unlikely to have acquired the virus at the protest, having taken great care to socially distance from others.

archiveTopNews.title: More people allowed at Queensland funerals from Tuesday
archiveTopNews.summary: One hundred people will be allowed to attend Queensland funerals from Tuesday after the state recorded no new cases of COVID-19 overnight. Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk and her deputy Steven Miles announced the relaxation on Monday morning. Chief Health Officer Dr Jeannette Young said funeral organisers would have to keep a list of attendees for eight weeks. The easing of funeral restrictions comes as the state recorded no new cases of COVID-19 on Monday, keeping the state's total steady at 1065.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorian coronavirus restrictions will be eased again on June 22, Premier confirms
archiveTopNews.summary: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has confirmed the state will further ease coronavirus restrictions on June 22, allowing cinemas and theatres to reopen and boosting customer capacity for hospitality venues. From June 22, up to 50 people will be allowed inside a range of venues including cinemas, theatres and cafes and people will be able to buy a drink at a pub or restaurant without ordering a meal. However, a density rule of 4 square metres per customer will remain.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW eases coronavirus restrictions further by dropping 50-person limit on indoor venues
archiveTopNews.summary: The NSW Government has announced another tranche of downgraded coronavirus restrictions, with the 50-person limit on pubs and restaurants to be lifted next month. From July 1, venues will be able to operate without capacity limits other than accommodating one person per four square metres. Outdoor venues with a capacity of up to 40,000 people can seat a quarter of that, a move to free restrictions on concerts and sporting events flagged by Scott Morrison after Friday's National Cabinet meeting.

archiveTopNews.title: Second coronavirus wave may cost Australia $80 billion
archiveTopNews.summary: Finance Minister Mathias Cormann has warned a second wave of coronavirus could cost the Australian economy $80 billion over the next two years. His calculation came as global share markets erupted into a sea of selling on fears of a pandemic resurgence, killing off optimism for a quick recovery. The Morrison government is concerned last week's anti-racism rallies, and more marches slated for this weekend, will spread the virus.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria records eight new coronavirus cases, including Melbourne doctor
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria has recorded eight new coronavirus infections since yesterday, including a doctor who worked across three clinics in Melbourne while potentially infectious. The Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) said the doctor had worked at Lilydale Medical Clinic, Croydon Family Practice and Cedars Medical Clinic in Coburg while asymptomatic. The three clinics have been closed for cleaning. Of the other new cases, six were detected in returned overseas travellers, while one is linked to the Rydges on Swanston outbreak.

archiveTopNews.title: Gathering limits relaxed for large venues under stage three coronavirus restrictions
archiveTopNews.summary: Large venues will be able to host more than 100 people and stadiums will be allowed to be filled to 25 per cent capacity under changes to stage three of lifting restrictions in Australia. Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced changes to the final stage of the roadmap to a COVIDSafe Australia after a meeting of the National Cabinet on Friday. He said the 100-person cap on gatherings will be removed and replaced with requirements to meet the one person per four square metres rule, allowing more people to be accommodated in larger venues.

archiveTopNews.title: International students could return to Australia next month if states open their borders
archiveTopNews.summary: Some international students could be allowed to return to Australia on a "pilot basis" as soon as next month but only if states agree to open their borders, Prime Minister Scott Morrison has announced. Addressing the media after a national cabinet meeting with state and territory leaders on Friday, Mr Morrison said the federal government was working with states and territories to enable international students to return in a "very controlled setting" and only under pre-approved plans provided by institutions. But the Prime Minister made clear that if the states and territories wanted international students to return, they would have to "open up borders for Australians".

archiveTopNews.title: Black Lives Matter protester among eight new coronavirus infections in Victoria
archiveTopNews.summary: A man in his 30s who went to Saturday's Black Lives Matter protest in Melbourne, which thousands of others attended, has tested positive for COVID-19. The man, who wore a mask to the protest, developed symptoms in the 24 hours after the demonstration, the state's Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton said on Thursday. Professor Sutton told reporters it was unlikely the man contracted the virus at the demonstration. However, he may have been infectious. Close contacts who spent more than 15 minutes directly with the person will be told to quarantine.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW coronavirus restrictions eased further, up to 20 people allowed in homes from Saturday
archiveTopNews.summary: NSW coronavirus restrictions will be further eased from Saturday, when households will be able to welcome up to 20 guests. Premier Gladys Berejiklian made the announcement this morning, and also revealed up to 20 people would be able to gather in groups outside from the same date. Food courts will also be open from Saturday, as long as people can abide by the four-square-metre rule.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison apologises for 'hurt or harm' caused by robodebt rollout
archiveTopNews.summary: Scott Morrison has apologised for any “hurt or harm” caused by the way the Coalition rolled out the controversial robodebt scheme, but the government services minister, Stuart Robert, has flagged regular debt collection will resume on the other side of the Covid-19 crisis. Scott Morrison has apologised for any “hurt or harm” caused by the way the Coalition rolled out the controversial robodebt scheme, but the government services minister, Stuart Robert, has flagged regular debt collection will resume on the other side of the Covid-19 crisis. Guardian Australia reported this week the true value of all welfare debts unlawfully issued is expected to easily exceed $1bn.

archiveTopNews.title: OECD calls for extension of coronavirus JobKeeper scheme as it warns Australia's economy could fall by 6.3 per cent
archiveTopNews.summary: Australia's economy could contract by 6.3 per cent this year if there is a second wave of coronavirus infections, according to the OECD's latest economic outlook. The report urges the Morrison Government to introduce further policy measures to support households and businesses, including extending income support payments, such as the $70 billion JobKeeper wage subsidy, and building social housing.

archiveTopNews.title: NZ travel bubble being delayed by Australian states' coronavirus border closures, Winston Peters says
archiveTopNews.summary: State border restrictions are holding up the resumption of travel between Australia and New Zealand, with leaders across the Tasman Sea becoming frustrated at the delays. New Zealand's Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters has complained about the "roadblock of federalism" getting in the way of plans to create a trans-Tasman 'travel bubble' between the two countries. While some states are now welcoming interstate tourists, others, such as Queensland and Western Australia, are still banning visitors from outside the state.

archiveTopNews.title: Ruby Princess was allowed to dock in Sydney before coronavirus test results so passengers didn't miss flights
archiveTopNews.summary: Passengers were allowed to disembark the Ruby Princess six hours before coronavirus test results came back, so they did not miss their flights. Today Dr Sean Tobin, NSW Chief Biosecurity Officer, fronted the inquiry into why 2700 passengers were allowed to disembark and subsequently carry the deadly disease around the country.
