He said the NSW Health decision to allow thousands of people off the ship instead of keeping them on board for just six hours was made so as not to disrupt their travel plans.

archiveTopNews.title: China warns students against studying in Australia in latest coronavirus escalation
archiveTopNews.summary: China on Tuesday urged students going overseas to study to think carefully before choosing Australia, due to a spate of racial incidents targeting Asians in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic. The Ministry of Education’s warning comes days after the Chinese culture and tourism ministry advised citizens against travelling to Australia due to racial discrimination and violence stemming from the coronavirus outbreak, which first emerged in China in late 2019. In its statement, the education ministry reminded "overseas students to conduct a good risk assessment and be cautious about choosing to go to Australia or return to Australia to study."

archiveTopNews.title: Coalition hints at 'further adjustments' to jobkeeper as Labor accuses it of breaking promise
archiveTopNews.summary: Mathias Cormann has indicated the government may make "further adjustments" to the $70bn jobkeeper program as Labor continues to target the Coalition for breaking a promise by withdrawing the wage subsidy from 120,000 childcare sector workers. Furthermore, on Tuesday the finance minister fronted the Senate Covid-19 committee to explain the $60bn discrepancy in the projected cost of the program, which he described as an "estimates variation" and for which the Treasury secretary, Steven Kennedy, said he took "full responsibility".

archiveTopNews.title: Australian economy appears to have avoided 'cycle of destruction': Treasury secretary
archiveTopNews.summary: The Australian economy is coming out of the coronavirus pandemic better than expected with unemployment unlikely to hit double figures, the Treasury secretary has revealed while taking responsibility for the $60 billion overestimation of the JobKeeper wage subsidy program. Steven Kennedy, giving evidence to a Senate inquiry into the government's policies to deal with the virus outbreak, said Australia was outperforming much of the rest of the world and appeared to have avoided a "cycle of destruction" that would weigh on the nation for years.

archiveTopNews.title: Free child care to end in July after Minister says it did its job during coronavirus
archiveTopNews.summary: The Federal Government will ditch its free childcare scheme next month, moving to reintroduce childcare subsidies for parents while ending the JobKeeper payment for workers in the sector. Changes announced by Federal Education Minister Dan Tehan today will see free child care come to an end on July 12, with a three-month, $708 million support package to be offered to the sector from the following day. Changes to government support for the sector will also see the JobKeeper payment ended for workers in the sector. Instead, the Government's $708 million support package will require employment levels be guaranteed to protect staff coming off of JobKeeper.

archiveTopNews.title: Those who attended protests do not need to isolate for two weeks, health officials say
archiveTopNews.summary: Those who attended protests across the nation at the weekend must get tested for coronavirus if they develop any symptoms, health officials have warned. Marches were held in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Adelaide in support of the Black Lives Matter movement and to protest Aboriginal deaths in custody. This morning the Australian Medical Association advised anyone who had attended a rally to self-isolate for two weeks. However Deputy Chief Medical Officer Dr Coatsworth said that was not the case, and only those with symptoms need to take such precautions.

archiveTopNews.title: ACT records first coronavirus case in a month as NSW has second day with no new infections
archiveTopNews.summary: The ACT has recorded its first case of COVID-19 in more than a month. A man aged in his 40s, who recently returned from overseas, was the ACT's first confirmed virus case since 4 May, ACT Health said in a statement on Sunday. This brings the ACT's confirmed cases to 108. The territory has suffered three deaths. Chief Health Officer Kerryn Coleman is confident there has been no risk to the broader ACT community.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus case in fruit picker who flew from Melbourne to Brisbane and Bundaberg causes public health alert in Queensland
archiveTopNews.summary: A mass public health alert has been issued after a fruit picker flew into Queensland from Victoria while infectious with coronavirus. Health Minister Steven Miles said the man received the diagnosis in the past 24 hours, taking the number of active cases in the state to four. He said the Melbourne man, in his 20s, flew to Brisbane on June 1 when he was infectious and then took a second flight the next day to Bundaberg, where he picked fruit and lived in shared accommodation. Contact tracing is underway for Virgin flights VA313, Melbourne to Brisbane, on June 1 and VA2905, Brisbane to Bundaberg, on June 2. Health authorities say Bundaberg and Brisbane should be on high alert for infections.

archiveTopNews.title: China warns citizens not to travel to Australia due to 'significant increase' in racial violence
archiveTopNews.summary: Trade Minister Simon Birmingham has rejected China's accusation of Australians attacking Chinese people during the coronavirus pandemic. China's Ministry of Culture and Tourism has advised the public to avoid travelling to Australia, citing racial discrimination and violence against Chinese people in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic. "There has been an alarming increase recently in acts of racial discrimination and violence against Chinese and Asians in Australia, due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic," the ministry said in a statement on Friday evening.

archiveTopNews.title: Black Lives Matter protests: Sydney rally given green light as court ruling overturned
archiveTopNews.summary: The Sydney “Stop All Black Deaths in Custody” rally has been declared an authorised public assembly after a late decision by the court of appeal as thousands of protesters rallied in cities and towns across Australia to march against Indigenous deaths in custody and the killing of unarmed US man George Floyd. The decision came minutes before the rally’s scheduled start at 3pm outside Town Hall on Saturday.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison tells people not to attend Black Lives Matter protests over coronavirus infection risk
archiveTopNews.summary: The Federal Government has sternly warned Australians not to attend large anti-racism protests slated for this weekend, saying the progress Australia has made in suppressing COVID-19 is at risk. As hundreds of protesters marched towards Parliament House to protest against racial injustice this morning, Prime Minister Scott Morrison urged all Australians to avoid mass gatherings and adhere to social-distancing rules. He said anyone who did attend further protests scheduled for this weekend would put their own health, and the health of others, at risk.

archiveTopNews.title: NT coronavirus restrictions are lifting for pubs, sport and cinemas as remote communities open
archiveTopNews.summary: The Northern Territory's journey to a "new normal" is complete — stage three coronavirus restrictions ease from noon Friday. Sweeping changes will today be made to what Territorians can do and all the changes together mean one thing: more freedom for Territorians. This includes changes to movement for remote communities, bars, sports and more. More information about the specific changes can be read in the article below.

archiveTopNews.title: Tens of thousands of West Australians return to work as government eases restrictions
archiveTopNews.summary: Premier Mark McGowan has urged people to go out and spend money in their own backyard, as tens of thousands of West Australians return to work on Saturday in light of eased pandemic restrictions. From midnight, the Kimberley, Shire of Ngaanyatjarraku and parts of the East Pilbara will reopen to the public after the federal government lifted the Commonwealth biosecurity restrictions this week. A new 2-square-metre rule will also replace the current one person per 4 square metre requirement and indoor and outdoor gatherings of up to 300 people per venue will be allowed. More information about the additional, specific changes can be read in the article below.

archiveTopNews.title: 'Keep that dream alive': PM announces $688 million HomeBuilder scheme for Australians looking to build or renovate
archiveTopNews.summary: Australians looking to build or renovate in the second half of the year will be able to get $25,000 from the federal government as part of a scheme aiming to keep the construction industry moving. The $688 million HomeBuilder package is available to owner-occupiers who sign a contract to start building or substantially renovating their property after June 4.

archiveTopNews.title: Qantas prepares to restart 40 per cent of domestic flying by end of July
archiveTopNews.summary: Qantas is preparing to scale up its domestic flying from its current 5 per cent of pre-pandemic levels to 40 per cent by the end of July, pending the reopening of state borders. The airline said on Thursday that travel demand was picking up sufficiently to start adding capacity to its Australian network, which would enable some of its 25,000 stood down employees to return to work. The airline said it would gradually start increasing capacity to reach 15 per cent by the end of June, or about 300 return flights per week. Qantas and Jetstar flights between Sydney and Melbourne would increase from 12 return flights a week to 67 by the end of June.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus cluster revealed in Melbourne's west as Premier urges people to avoid Black Lives Matter protest
archiveTopNews.summary: Victorian health authorities have revealed a waste management facility in Melbourne's west went into lockdown last week after staff tested positive to coronavirus. Meanwhile, Mr Andrews has urged people to stay away from a planned protest this week in support of the Black Lives Matter movement. Mr Andrews said he would prefer the protest did not go ahead, but understood Victoria Police shutting it down may do nothing but "inflame a volatile situation".

archiveTopNews.title: "Travel bubble" could open between select states in time for school holidays
archiveTopNews.summary: A travel bubble between select states could become a reality in just a month, which could herald good news for families wanting a domestic break during the school holidays. Authorities in South Australia, Canberra and Tasmania are reportedly considering the measures which would allow residents to move freely between the borders, given their relatively low number of coronavirus cases. South Australia's premier Steven Marshall has hinted he wants to see travel open up between Western Australia, the Northern Territory, Tasmania, the ACT and even potentially Queensland.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia enters first recession in 29 years after blow from bushfires and coronavirus
archiveTopNews.summary: Australia has entered its first recession for 29 years after the economy went backwards by 0.3% in the March quarter, with the impact of bushfires and the coronavirus ending the nation’s extraordinary, uninterrupted run of economic growth. The treasurer, Josh Frydenberg, told reporters a recession was inevitable after the Australian Bureau of Statistics released national accounts showing gross domestic product fell 0.3% in the quarter. The economy grew only 1.4% over the past 12 months, which is the weakest performance since the global financial crisis.

archiveTopNews.title: Australian universities facing $16bn black hole as Covid-19 student numbers plummet
archiveTopNews.summary: Universities claim they will lose up to $16bn by 2023 due to the impact of Covid-19, according to new modelling. Universities Australia has raised the stakes in lobbying for an industry assistance package or relaxed visa conditions to facilitate international students by revealing it now expects members to lose between $3.1bn and $4.8bn this year alone. The university sector is struggling after a series of changes that excluded all public universities from the jobkeeper wage subsidy and the collapse of a deal with the National Tertiary Education Union to accept pay cuts in return for saving up to 12,000 jobs.

archiveTopNews.title: Tasmania to lift coronavirus restrictions ahead of schedule
archiveTopNews.summary: Tasmania is relaxing coronavirus restrictions early, allowing more movement around the state ahead of the coming long weekend. The state was due to move to "stage two" of its recovery "roadmap" on June 15, but many restrictions will now be lifted from 3:00pm this Friday. Speaking this morning, Premier Peter Gutwein said camping and overnight stays would be permitted, and pubs and clubs, excluding nightclubs, would be allowed up to 40 patrons.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW coronavirus restrictions on gyms to be lifted from June 13
archiveTopNews.summary: NSW coronavirus restrictions on a raft of fitness facilities including gyms, yoga studios and indoor pools will be lifted next week, as new infections in the state flatline. From Saturday, June 13, indoor fitness activities like yoga, pilates or group training sessions will be permitted, but class sizes will be capped at 10 people. Indoor pools and saunas, as well as tattoo and massage parlours will be allowed to reopen from the same date, with restricted numbers. Children's community sport competitions will be permitted to restart from July 1.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus restrictions continue to ease nationwide
archiveTopNews.summary: Australians will experience more freedom as much of the country enters a new phase of COVID-19 restrictions. Deputy Chief Medical Officer Nick Coatsworth says the lifting of restrictions is a balancing act between the socio-economic benefit from their removal and the public health risk. The more flexible restrictions – which differ across the states – will mean more movement in public places, including pubs, cafes, and restaurants. However authorities continue to urge the public to practise safe hygiene and social distancing measures.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison says households may get cash grants for home renovations
archiveTopNews.summary: New home construction and major renovation projects could be boosted through cash grants under a federal government coronavirus recovery plan. The ailing entertainment sector is also likely to receive stimulus, with the focus shifting from economy-wide packages to targeted assistance. Prime Minister Scott Morrison confirmed the government was considering giving householders cash grants for home renovations. He said it would be important any construction industry measures helped local tradies rather than major contractors.

archiveTopNews.title: Queensland eases coronavirus restrictions early: Here's what's changing
archiveTopNews.summary: From midday tomorrow, Queenslanders will be able to enjoy unrestricted travel throughout the state. Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk said she had been able to bring forward intra-state travel because of so few coronavirus cases, but also because of the detailed plans submitted by the tourism industry. Furthermore, 20 people be allowed to dine-in at restaurants and cafes, to attend a gym, cinema, library, museum, art gallery, or place of worship.  The same rule will apply to bars, but patrons must be seated.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus state of emergency extended in Victoria as cases two clusters continue to rise
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria's state of emergency has been extended by three weeks to ensure the new restrictions that come into effect on Monday can be enforced. This comes as there was a net increase of four new cases of COVID-19, including new cases linked to outbreaks at the Rydges hotel and a family group at Keilor Downs and up to 100 students in Melbourne's west are in isolation following exposure to a positive case linked to the Keilor Downs cluster. Health Minister Jenny Mikakos said the state of emergency, which will now expire at 11:59pm on June 21, was extended to give the Chief Health Officer the powers needed to enforce new restrictions that come into effect on Monday.

archiveTopNews.title: WA records three new coronavirus cases, including a three-year-old child
archiveTopNews.summary: Western Australia has recorded three new cases of COVID-19 overnight, including a three-year-old-child. The other two cases are a woman in her 60s and man in his 30s. All three cases returned from overseas and are currently in hotel quarantine. The three-year-old contracted the virus from a known contact. Western Australia's total number of cases is now 589, of which 28 are active.

archiveTopNews.title: Melbourne primary school students in quarantine as Keilor Downs cluster grows
archiveTopNews.summary: A class of year two children in Victoria has been placed into quarantine for a fortnight after a student tested positive to coronavirus. All classmates of the student at Holy Eucharist Primary School who tested positive will go into quarantine for two weeks. The student was in close contact with a person linked to a family cluster in Keilor Downs in Melbourne's west, including a student at Keilor Downs Secondary College. The cluster increased by three overnight to a total of 11.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus-hit Ruby Princess passengers contacted about crew member with tuberculosis
archiveTopNews.summary: Passengers onboard the coronavirus-afflicted Ruby Princess have been issued another health warning after a crew member was diagnosed with tuberculosis this week. NSW Health said the male crew member was being treated in Sydney's Royal Prince Alfred Hospital. NSW Health said the risk of infection for passengers was low and requires "close and prolonged contact."

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus Australia: NSW records no new cases for the first time in almost three weeks
archiveTopNews.summary: NSW has recorded no new cases of COVID-19 for the first time in almost three weeks as the easing of restrictions around the state nears. Zero cases were recorded from 9500 tests in the 24 hours to 8pm on Friday, NSW Health said in a statement, with one person currently in intensive care. Just 11 cases of COVID-19 have been recorded in NSW in the past 11 days - seven from overseas travellers and four with an unknown local source.

archiveTopNews.title: PM pledges $131.4b towards Australia's public hospitals in wake of COVID-19
archiveTopNews.summary: The Federal Government will pour $131.4 billion into Australia's public hospitals to future-proof the health system against crises like COVID-19. Announcing the huge cash injection in a national address this afternoon, Prime Minister Scott Morrison said the money will be used to improve health outcomes for all Australians. The government will start proceedings with an additional $34.4 billion in funding to hospitals from July 1 this year.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus restrictions eased in WA with almost all businesses set to reopen under new rules
archiveTopNews.summary: West Australians can gather in groups of up to 100 people from June 6 as the state moves to phase three of relaxing coronavirus restrictions, with the "vast majority" of businesses affected by the lockdown permitted to reopen. Up to 300 people will be permitted in some settings, like for indoor and outdoor venues, with multiple divided spaces with up to 100 people in each space. The Premier said Western Australia would be the first state to move away from the one person per four square metres rule under phase three, replacing it with a one person per two square metres rule.

archiveTopNews.title: Scrapping jobkeeper too early risks Australian economy falling off a cliff, Covid inquiry told
archiveTopNews.summary: The governor of the Reserve Bank has warned the government the jobkeeper program may need to be kept going beyond its current cut-off date to avoid the Australian economy falling off a cliff. Statements made by the RBA governor, Philip Lowe, and the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority chairman, Wayne Byres, about the risk of economic collapse when the jobkeeper program expires at the end of September will increase pressure on the Morrison government to defy a ginger group of Coalition backbenchers and extend stimulus into the new year.

archiveTopNews.title: Tourism taskforce pushing ahead with 'ambitious' plan to kickstart air travel to New Zealand, Pacific
archiveTopNews.summary: Australians will be allowed to travel to NZ and the Pacific from July if an 'ambitious' timetable produced by the Tourism Restart Taskforce goes ahead. The taskforce meets once a week to discuss a plan to reopen the tourism industry, with government representatives often in attendance. The taskforce recently approved a timetable covering domestic travel and events, and possible international travel resumption dates. Travel between Australia and New Zealand and the Pacific would restart by July 1 , while September 10 was earmarked for potential travel to countries deemed "safe". All international travel could be resumed by 2021 if the plan is approved.

archiveTopNews.title: Queensland man, 30, becomes youngest person to die from coronavirus in Australia
archiveTopNews.summary: A 30-year-old Queensland man has died from coronavirus, making him Australia's youngest COVID-19 victim to date. The man's partner is currently being isolated at Rockhampton Hospital and is also showing COVID-19 symptoms. Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk said the man was from Blackwater in central Queensland and urged anyone in the area with flu-like symptoms to get tested urgently.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW Government freezes staff salaries to save $3 billion amid coronavirus pandemic
archiveTopNews.summary: The NSW Government will freeze pay rises for public sector workers for 12 months, as it deals with rising unemployment across the state due to the coronavirus pandemic. Under the current wages policy, hundreds of thousands of public sector employees can pursue a 2.5 per cent pay rise each year. However, under the wage freeze policy, salaries will remain unchanged for 12 months. Premier Gladys Berejiklian said the measure will save about $3 billion and has assured government workers there will be no job losses.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison outlines 'JobMaker' plan for post-coronavirus economic recovery
archiveTopNews.summary: The prime minister on Tuesday unveiled part of the coalition's economic plan designed to claw the nation back from pandemic-induced pain.  Under Mr Morrison's plan, funding would be more closely linked to skill gaps based on what businesses need. Industry will be given greater power to shape training, with pilot schemes across human services, digital technologies and mining used as examples for other sectors. Mr Morrison made the case to ditch a "clunky and unresponsive" system in favour of more consistency across states and greater transparency around spending. Mr Morrison will flag changes to the funding model which sees $1.5 billion of federal cash flow to state governments annually for skills and training.

archiveTopNews.title: Human trials of potential coronavirus vaccine begin in Melbourne
archiveTopNews.summary: Australia's first human trials of a potential COVID-19 vaccine have begun in Melbourne, with about 130 people involved in the program. Clinical research organisation Nucleus Network will be in charge of the early stages of testing the vaccine NVX-CoV2373, before the trial expands to Brisbane within a week. If it is successful, researchers hope 100 million doses of the vaccine can be made by the end of the year and 1.5 billion next year. Preliminary results for phase one are expected in July, and phase two results by the end of the year.

archiveTopNews.title: South Australia records first new coronavirus case in 19 days amid easing restrictions
archiveTopNews.summary: South Australia has recorded its first COVID-19 case in 19 days — an overseas traveller who was given an exemption from quarantine. SA Health said the woman aged in her 50s had travelled from overseas to Victoria where she had been quarantined in a hotel for less than a week, before travelling to South Australia. She was given an exemption to fly to South Australia for "compelling family reasons" and was tested on arrival at Adelaide Airport. The new case comes amid an accelerated easing of coronavirus restrictions in South Australia. It is the first new case since that of a man in his 70s was declared on May 7, and follows a declaration of no remaining active cases which occurred just over a week later.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus restrictions to be relaxed in South Australia ahead of schedule
archiveTopNews.summary: Stage two restrictions were originally due to ease on June 8, but that was previously brought forward to June 5 and now to Monday, June 1. Cinemas, theatres, galleries, museums, beauty salons, gyms and indoor fitness centres across South Australia will be able to open from next Monday, with the SA Government bringing forward the relaxation of coronavirus restrictions. Those venues, along with pubs, bars, restaurants and cafes, will be able to admit up to 80 patrons, provided they can contain them to groups of 20 in discrete rooms or areas within the business. Furthermore, up to 50 mourners will be allowed at funerals, non-contact outdoor sport will be able to resume on June 1 and competition for outdoor contact sports can resume from June 25.

archiveTopNews.title: Schools are reopening, so here's a guide to the situation in each state and territory
archiveTopNews.summary: Government advice on whether students should attend schools amid the ongoing coronavirus situation varies widely across Australia, and has sometimes led to confusion and controversy. Some states still have restrictions on school attendance while some states have never had restrictions on school attendance; however Prime Minister Scott Morrison wants all public schools to return to face-to-face learning by June. Here's the latest on when schools will reopen in your state or territory, if they haven't already.

archiveTopNews.title: Australian active coronavirus cases dip below 500 for the first time since March as recoveries outpace new infections
archiveTopNews.summary: The number of active cases of coronavirus in Australia has dipped below 500 as the number of Australians recovering from the disease continues to outstrip the number of new infections recorded each day. More than 6,500 people have recovered from the virus, while a further 102 people have died due to COVID-19 since the pandemic took hold. It leaves just 484 currently infected with COVID-19. While data on recovered cases was not consistently reported earlier than April 5, the total number of confirmed cases in Australia was last below 500 on March 17.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria eases coronavirus restrictions; what you can do from June 1
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria has announced it will further ease coronavirus restrictions from June 1, reopening parks and allowing up to 20 people to gather at once. Restaurants and cafes will be allowed to seat and serve more customers, but bars serving alcohol without food must remain closed and people are encouraged to continue working from home when possible. A breakdown of the new restrictions can be found in the article below.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW beauty salons can reopen from June 1 as coronavirus restrictions ease
archiveTopNews.summary: Beauty salons will be allowed to reopen in New South Wales on June 1. This includes nail salons, tanning salons and waxing salons, as long as the business has a COVID-safe plan in place and there are no more than ten clients in a business at one time. Salons must still adhere to strict social distancing regulations including the four square metre rule, limiting the number of patrons they can treat at a time, and create a COVID-safe plan before their re-opening.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison dismisses calls for Josh Frydenberg to front Covid-19 inquiry over jobkeeper
archiveTopNews.summary: Labor will attempt to pressure the treasurer, Josh Frydenberg, to appear before the Senate’s Covid-19 inquiry to explain the “$60bn black hole” in the jobkeeper program – but the government has dismissed the call as a political stunt. However, Prime Minister Scott Morrison denied the revision (which means just 3.5 million workers are likely to be covered by the $1,500 fortnightly payment, not the 6.5 million estimated at one point) raised any issue with the government’s overall economic competence.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW govt eyes opening gyms, beauty salons
archiveTopNews.summary: The NSW government has flagged the "imminent" re-opening of gyms and beauty salons as the state over the next two weeks prepares for a landmark easing of COVID-19 restrictions. The government remains cautious yet bullish after three cases of coronavirus were recorded over the preceding 24 hours. All three were overseas acquired - two from Pakistan and one from the USA - and were already in hotel quarantine meaning they didn't represent a risk of onward infection. Premier Gladys Berejiklian has announced that from June 1, up to 50 people will be allowed in restaurants, pubs and cafes. Regional travel restrictions will also ease while museums, galleries and libraries will also be allowed to open.

archiveTopNews.title: Government's $60b accounting bungle ups pressure to extend JobKeeper scheme as economy recovers from COVID-19
archiveTopNews.summary: The Australian Government is facing tough questions about whether they plan to reallocate the $60 billion windfall following the ATO's JobKeeper bungle. The Government had budgeted for the JobKeeper scheme to cost $130 billion however the actual price tag has been reduced to $70 billion after major miscalculations by the Australian Taxation Office due to a confusing question on the application sheet. Australians were told six and a half million workers would receive these payments but that number has been revised down to three and a half million following the revision of figures. With $60 billion now on the table, various stakeholders are trying to get their hands on a portion of the money with calls to extend the JobKeeper scheme to those still in need.

archiveTopNews.title: JobKeeper numbers cut by 3 million after Federal Government reveals accounting bungle in coronavirus stimulus program
archiveTopNews.summary: The number of people on JobKeeper has been revised down by 3 million, with Treasury and the Australian Tax Office (ATO) blaming businesses for making "significant errors" in their applications. The estimated cost of the program has been nearly halved from $130 billion to about $70 billion. In a statement, Treasury and the ATO said the mistake came from businesses reporting how much financial assistance they expected to receive, instead of how many employees they thought would be eligible.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW coronavirus restrictions relaxed for restaurants, pubs and cafes, Premier Gladys Berejiklian reveals
archiveTopNews.summary: Premier Gladys Berejiklian says pubs, cafes and restaurants will be able to serve up to 50 people at a time from June 1, as NSW coronavirus cases continue to decline. The Premier described expanding the social-distancing limits as a "big step" in the state's economic recovery from COVID-19. Under the new measures, hospitality venues will be required to adhere to strict guidelines to operate: each patron must have at least four-square-metres of space; bookings can be no larger than 10 people; no patrons will be allowed to stand, mingle or dance; and shared cutlery and buffets are also banned.

archiveTopNews.title: SA to move to stage two of COVID-19 restrictions on June 5, with indoor dining allowed from Friday
archiveTopNews.summary: South Australia will lift coronavirus restrictions earlier than first hoped, following a clean sweep without COVID-19 cases. From this Friday, cafes and restaurants will be allowed indoor dining for groups of up to 10 in addition to existing outdoor dining limits. Alcohol service will be allowed for up to 10 people indoors and 10 people outdoors. Premier Steven Marshall has also announced the state will move to stage two of restrictions from Friday June 5, ahead of the long weekend.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW pressure to reopen state borders triggers accusations of bullying from WA and Queensland premiers
archiveTopNews.summary: The New South Wales premier, Gladys Berejiklian, remains in a sparring contest with her Queensland and Western Australian counterparts, as pressure to reopen state borders triggers accusations of bullying between leaders and threats of travel restrictions until September. In a week without a national cabinet meeting, the WA premier, Mark McGowan, and Queensland premier, Annastacia Palaszczuk, have blasted Berejiklian for calling on them to lift bans on interstate travel, with the latter saying she would not be “lectured” by a state that has recorded more Covid-19 cases.

archiveTopNews.title: Australian domestic travel explained: where can I fly and is it too soon to plan an interstate holiday?
archiveTopNews.summary: Australian states are tentatively easing its state lockdowns after flattening the curve, attention has turned to tourism, flights and reopening state borders. This article provides a breakdown of the most pressing questions when it comes to air travel and holidays during the pandemic. These answers are based on comments from politicians, experts and industry stakeholders and should not be treated as medical or legal advice.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorian health officials use COVIDSafe app data for first time to trace infected person's contacts
archiveTopNews.summary: Victorian health officials have used the COVIDSafe app to trace an infected person's close contacts for the first time since the app launched late last month. The Department of Health and Human Services said a coronavirus-infected person, who had the COVIDSafe app installed on their phone, was identified on Monday night. Victorian Deputy Chief Health Officer Annaliese van Diemen said the app was used to identify a close contact of the infected person who had been missed in initial screening.

archiveTopNews.title: Retail sales post record plunge in April, as coronavirus panic buying subsides
archiveTopNews.summary: Shoppers who spent March panic buying tinned food, toilet paper and pasta shut their wallets in April, sending retail sales plunging last month. Preliminary figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) show a 17.9 per cent drop in retail turnover — the steepest monthly fall on record. It is the realisation of the 'pay back' economists had warned about, with the April fall more than double the record 8.5 per cent climb in sales in March. Transaction data from the major banks show a pick up in spending in May and consumer confidence has recovered some ground, but economists do not see a fast recovery.

archiveTopNews.title: Chinese embassy ridicules Australia for claiming vindication for global coronavirus inquiry
archiveTopNews.summary: China's embassy in Canberra says it is a joke for Australia to claim it has been vindicated by international support for a coronavirus inquiry. Australia was the second country, after the United States, to call for an independent inquiry into the global pandemic, a move which sparked a diplomatic row with China. But last night, at a meeting of the World Health Assembly (WHA) in Geneva, China indicated it would likely back a European Union motion that called for an "impartial, independent and comprehensive" evaluation of the response to the global outbreak. However, Beijing's embassy in Canberra issued a statement saying the inquiry being considered by the WHA was "totally different" to the one Australia proposed, saying that to claim vindication was "nothing but a joke".

archiveTopNews.title: Australia's coronavirus death toll hits 100 after 93-year-old Sydney aged care resident dies
archiveTopNews.summary: Another elderly resident of the Newmarch House nursing home in Sydney has died after becoming infected with COVID-19, taking the national death toll to 100. Operator Anglicare confirmed 93-year-old Alice Bacon died on Tuesday morning, raising the NSW tally to 49. Seventeen residents have now died from COVID-19 at the western Sydney nursing home where about 70 people have been infected with the virus.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW is unable to use Covidsafe app’s data for contact tracing
archiveTopNews.summary: Sydney has not yet been able to use the COVIDSafe app for contact tracing. In nearly a month since it launched, more than 5.87 million Australians have downloaded and registered to use the Covidsafe contact-tracing app, which is designed to make it easier for state health officials to find close contacts in the event a user tests positive for coronavirus. Last week, state health department contact tracers received training in how to access the data, but no states have yet reported using the data for contact. NSW Health has tested the data but has had issues integrating it into the existing contact-tracing methods.

archiveTopNews.title: Andrews reveals $2.7b for building blitz, including $1.1b for schools
archiveTopNews.summary: The Victorian government has announced $2.7 billion in funding for building projects across the state, led by about $1.1 billion to build new schools and classrooms. Some of the $1.18 billion for schools and education will go towards fulfilling previously announced projects, such as the new 3000-student Greater Shepparton Secondary College – one of a total of 10 new schools in growth areas included in the funding – while $114 million will go towards 250 demountable classrooms. More widely there will be $382 million in upgrades for tourism destinations such as new mountain bike trails in the Ararat Hills, along with $328 million for resurfacing and patching roads, repairs at about 15 train stations and 300 kilometres of regional train track works. Premier Daniel Andrews said he expected the $2.7 billion package to create 3700 construction jobs, many for Victorians out of work due to the coronavirus pandemic.

archiveTopNews.title: McDonald's closes 12 restaurants in Victoria after delivery driver tests positive
archiveTopNews.summary: Twelve McDonald's outlets have been closed in Victoria due to a coronavirus-infected truck driver, while the state announces $2.7 billion to help revive the economy. The fast-food outlets will be shut and deep-cleaned after the driver made deliveries while he was asymptomatic and unaware he had COVID-19. The chain says no employee has tested positive in connection to the driver and customers are not at risk. "Out of an abundance of caution, we have made the decision to close and conduct a deep clean of 12 restaurants in Victoria, following confirmation a truck driver for an external service provider has tested positive for COVID-19," McDonald's said in a statement.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW public school students to return to classrooms full time after coronavirus shutdown
archiveTopNews.summary: Students at NSW public schools will return to classrooms full time from next Monday after weeks of remote learning. NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian will confirm the May 25 start date tomorrow. Most students have been attending school one day a week since last week. Last month the NSW Government announced students across the state would make a staggered return from May 11. At the time Ms Berejiklian said she hoped students would be back in classrooms full time by term three, which does not start until July 21.

archiveTopNews.title: Coalition of 62 countries backs joint Australian, EU push for independent inquiry into coronavirus outbreak
archiveTopNews.summary: A coalition of 62 countries has backed a joint Australian and European Union push for an independent inquiry into the coronavirus outbreak ahead of a crucial World Health Assembly (WHA) meeting tomorrow in Geneva. Australia was the first nation to call for an independent inquiry into how the coronavirus started. That drew furious condemnation from Beijing, which accused Australia of launching a political attack on China. But international support for the idea has been steadily growing. The Morrison Government has now swung its diplomatic firepower behind the European Union, which has also been pressing for an investigation while taking a more conciliatory line with Beijing.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorian cafes, restaurants and pubs to reopen for dining in June in easing of coronavirus restrictions
archiveTopNews.summary: Victorians will be allowed to enjoy a meal inside cafes, restaurants and pubs from next month as part of a staged reopening of the hospitality industry, Premier Daniel Andrews has announced. Mr Andrews said the reopening would be subject to "a long and extensive set of rules" covering matters such as cleaning, temperature checks and screening of staff to ensure they were not unwell. Venues will be required to take the contact details of every customer to help with rapid contact tracing. Existing physical distancing requirements will continue to apply, meaning each person will need four square metres of space, and tables will need to be spaced at least 1.5 metres apart.

archiveTopNews.title: More than one million Australians tested for coronavirus, but authorities warn pandemic isn't over
archiveTopNews.summary: Australia has now surpassed more than one million COVID-19 tests since the start of the pandemic. While COVID-19 restrictions are being loosened around Australia, health authorities continue to warn against complacency. Deputy Chief Medical Officer Michael Kidd said Australians over 70 and those who are immunocompromised or have other health problems should still stay at home apart from essential outings. He also warned that it's important Australians are adhering to physical distancing measures so that there will not be a resurgence of COVID-19.

archiveTopNews.title: SA pledges $1 million package for coronavirus-hit musicians and venues
archiveTopNews.summary: South Australian artists, bands and live music venues hit hard by the COVID-19 pandemic will receive state government support with a $1 million package. The Music Development Office Project will help musicians who write and perform original music as well as local businesses who support those artists' development, delivery or production. Grants up to $5,000 are available to artists while music businesses can apply for up to $20,000.

archiveTopNews.title: Melbourne's west a COVID-19 hotspot as clusters continue to grow
archiveTopNews.summary: Melbourne’s inner north-west is emerging as the state’s new coronavirus red zone, government data shows. After outbreaks in McDonald’s restaurants in Craigieburn and Fawkner, as well as the huge and still-growing cluster at Cedar Meats, health department data shows the council areas of Hume and Brimbank now make up a quarter of Melbourne’s active cases. Brimbank takes in parts of Brooklyn, the suburb where the Cedar Meats meat-processing plant linked to 98 cases of COVID-19 so far is located. The council area has 14 active cases of COVID-19 as of Saturday afternoon, the most in the state.

archiveTopNews.title: International travel won’t return to normal until 2023 despite coronavirus restrictions lifted in Australia
archiveTopNews.summary: International travel has been severely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic and won’t return to normal until 2023. The International Air Transport Association (IATA), based in Geneva, has released new data showing how the pandemic has affected air travel and when it’s expected to recover. The new data revealed long-haul, international travel was the most severely impacted area of air travel and will take years to recover. They suggested that if international markets open, levels of global passenger demand next year are expected to be 24 per cent lower than 2019 levels. Furthermore, an IATA survey conducted in April revealed that 58 percent of recent travellers are likely to initially travel domestically.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus restrictions successfully being eased, domestic holidays may be back on cards by July, Scott Morrison says
archiveTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison says domestic holidays are on the horizon - hopefully by July - as Australia continues along the road back from coronavirus restrictions. He said all states and territories were moving through stage one of eased restrictions successfully, one week after National Cabinet agreed on a three-stage approach to lift restrictions. Mr Morrison said as restrictions ease, "borders will fall" across Australia, opening the domestic tourism market to potentially billions of dollars in business.

archiveTopNews.title: Victoria records another 21 coronavirus cases as McDonald's and Cedar Meats outbreaks grow
archiveTopNews.summary: A second McDonald's outlet has closed for cleaning in Melbourne after a worker was diagnosed with COVID-19, as Victoria recorded 21 new coronavirus cases. In a statement, the fast food giant said its Craigieburn store had been closed for cleaning and staff were advised to self-quarantine for 14 days and get tested after the worker tested positive. It came as the state's total number of coronavirus cases rose by 21, including two new cases which were linked to the Fawkner McDonald's franchise. The outbreak at the Fawkner outlet is now linked to 10 of the state's COVID-19 cases, while the cluster at the Cedar Meats Australia abattoir in Brooklyn is linked to 91 infections.

archiveTopNews.title: Unemployment rate in Australia jumps to 6.2% due to Covid-19 as 600,000 jobs lost
archiveTopNews.summary: The jobless rate in Australia has hit the highest level since September 2015, with seasonally adjusted employment falling by 594,300 in April as the economic shock of the coronavirus pandemic cut a swathe through the labour market. Scott Morrison told reporters in Canberra the job losses recorded to date were devastating, and he warned more would follow. The prime minister said the unemployment rate jumping a full percentage point in a month, from 5.2% to 6.2%, was “terribly shocking, although not totally unexpected”.

archiveTopNews.title: Questions remain over whether data collected by Covidsafe app could be accessed by US law enforcement
archiveTopNews.summary: The federal government has reassured the public that Covidsafe data held by Amazon will not be able to be accessed by US law enforcement, but a parliamentary committee is currently investigating separate legislation that would pave the way for US law enforcement to access data held in Australia. A major concern held by those critical of the app is that the data is being hosted in Australia by US tech giant Amazon Web Services, and any data held by the company in Australia would be subject to the US Cloud Act – a law which can force US companies to hand over data to US law enforcement regardless of where that data is held. The defence minister, Marise Payne, argued that because the Covidsafe legislation makes “any transfer of data to any country outside Australia … a criminal offence under the provisions of the bill”, US law enforcement would not be able to get the Covidsafe data.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia appoints first deputy chief medical officer for mental health as part of coronavirus response
archiveTopNews.summary: Australia has a new mental health official to help prevent a spike in suicides related to the coronavirus. Former chief psychiatrist of Victoria Ruth Vine has been appointed as the country's first deputy chief medical officer for mental health. Professor Vine will listen to community concerns and provide advice to the federal government, with a focus on anxiety linked to social distancing and economic stress. Health Minister Greg Hunt announced the appointment on Wednesday, saying the COVID-19 pandemic, bushfires and drought had affected Australians' mental health.

archiveTopNews.title: Government requests advice on link between coronavirus and illness resembling Kawasaki disease in children
archiveTopNews.summary: The Federal Government is requesting urgent advice about a mystery illness that has killed at least three children in the United States, including on whether the condition could be linked to COVID-19. The inflammatory condition, which resembles Kawasaki disease or toxic shock syndrome, has been noted in children in the United Kingdom, Italy and the US, where 70 children have been diagnosed with it in New York. No conclusive link between the inflammatory illness and COVID-19 has been made by scientists, and while it has appeared in some children who have COVID-19, other children diagnosed with the condition have not tested positive for coronavirus. Health Minister Greg Hunt said officials were keen to learn more about the illness, but stressed there were no known cases in Australia.

archiveTopNews.title: Church in Australia selling bleach as a coronavirus treatment fined $151,200
archiveTopNews.summary: The Australian chapter of an international church selling and promoting bleach as a cure for COVID-19 has been issued infringement notices totalling $151,200. The Genesis II Church of Health and Healing has been claiming chlorine dioxide is a "miracle cure". For years it has sold the industrial bleach as Miracle Mineral Solution (MMS), stating it can cure things like autism, acne, cancer, diabetes and now COVID-19.  Following an investigation by 7.30 last week, the Therapeutic Goods Administration today announced it had issued 12 infringement notices totalling $151,200 to MMS Australia for alleged unlawful advertising of Miracle Mineral Solution and other medicines.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus restrictions to cut $50 billion from Australia's economy, Josh Frydenberg says
archiveTopNews.summary: Treasurer Josh Frydenberg says Australia's coronavirus restrictions have wiped the equivalent of $50 billion from the nation's economy. He confirmed Treasury's forecast that the economy will shrink by $50 billion, or 10 per cent, in the June quarter amid the coronavirus restrictions that have shut down swathes of businesses. Mr Frydenberg also outlined the boost to jobs and GDP expected during the three-stage relaxing of restrictions between now and July. Once the third stage is reached, the economy should be $9.4 billion a month better off and 850,000 Australians should be back in work.

archiveTopNews.title: Red-meat processors have beef sales to China suspended as trade barriers escalate
archiveTopNews.summary: China has imposed an import ban on four Australian abattoirs in an apparent escalation of Beijing's trade war tactics. The blacklisting of the red meat abattoirs — three in Queensland and one in NSW — comes just days after China flagged plans to introduce an 80 per cent tariff on Australian barley, bringing the trade to its knees. These four meatworks represent 35 per cent of beef exports to China, a trade that had been on track to reach $3.5 billion this year. There are fears the barriers introduced by Australia's largest trading partner are in retaliation to Prime Minister Scott Morrison's demand for an independent investigation into the COVID-19 outbreak.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus: Canberra cafes and restaurants to reopen from this weekend with restrictions
archiveTopNews.summary: Canberra cafes and restaurants will be able to reopen from midnight on Friday, but with a 10-customer limit in place. The move is part of the first stage of the ACT government's relaxation of coronavirus restrictions. Pubs and bars would only be able to open if alcohol served was accompanied by a meal. National parks, playgrounds and nature reserves will also open, except those shut for remediation after bushfires.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus restrictions eased in Victoria to allow five visitors to a household and outdoor gatherings of 10 people
archiveTopNews.summary: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has announced "a small first step" in the relaxation of the state's coronavirus restrictions. The changes come into effect at 11:59pm on Tuesday and will be in place until the end of May. Notably, the restriction changes mean that residents can now invite five friends or family members over to their house; go hiking, fishing, hunting, diving, prospecting, boating, go for a walk or play non-contact sport together outdoors in groups of up to 10 people; have more guests for weddings and funerals and more. More details on the restrictions lifted can be found in the article.

archiveTopNews.title: Ten arrested and police officer injured at protest against Victoria’s Covid-19 lockdown laws
archiveTopNews.summary: Ten people have been arrested and one police officer has been hospitalised after demonstrators who gathered in Melbourne’s CBD to protest against “self-isolating, social distancing, tracking apps [and] 5G being installed” clashed with police enforcing Victoria’s lockdown laws. Victoria police said on Sunday that 10 people, including two organisers, were arrested after more than 100 people turned out on the steps of Victoria’s parliament on Sunday in contravention of emergency powers restricting gatherings introduced to slow the spread of Covid-19.

archiveTopNews.title: WA to ease coronavirus restrictions from May 18, with 20-person gatherings allowed
archiveTopNews.summary: West Australian Premier Mark McGowan has announced a roadmap for the reopening of the state's economy, doubling the number of people allowed at non-work gatherings and removing some regional travel borders. Notably, up to 20 people will be allowed to gather indoors and outdoors, pubs, restaurants and cafes may have 20 patrons dine in and regional travel boundaries have dropped from 13 to four. More details on the restrictions lifted can be found in the article.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW to ease lockdown restrictions from Friday
archiveTopNews.summary: NSW will further ease COVID-19 restrictions from this Friday, with cafes, restaurants, playgrounds and outdoor pools making the cut for early reopening. Premier Gladys Berejiklian said "the changes will allow NSW to fire up the economy, while allowing more personal freedoms." Notably, NSW residents will be permitted to have outdoor gatherings of up to 10 people, visits to a household of up to five people, while cafes and restaurants can seat 10 patrons at any one time. More details on the restrictions lifted can be found in the article.

archiveTopNews.title: How travel will resume around Australia as coronavirus restrictions ease in each state and territory
archiveTopNews.summary: While Prime Minister Scott Morrison has made it very clear that any hopes of an overseas adventure should be shelved for "the foreseeable future", the prospects for regional and interstate travel are more promising. As each state and territory unveils its individual plans, in line with the Federal Government's three-step framework announced on Friday, the road back to domestic travel becomes slightly clearer. There's still much to be decided, and a number of states are yet to lay out their plans. This article outlines all the information about the regional and interstate travel plans in each state and territory that has been released so far.

archiveTopNews.title: The three-step plan for reopening Australia after Covid-19 and what Stage 1, 2 and 3 looks like
archiveTopNews.summary: Scott Morrison and the chief medical officer, Brendan Murphy, have laid out a three-step plan to reopen Australia after the coronavirus crisis. Morrison said he hoped step three could be achieved in July, but it would be up to each state and territory when they moved from one step to the next.

archiveTopNews.title: Federal government delays banking royal commission reforms due to pandemic
archiveTopNews.summary: Misbehaving bankers and financiers have been given a six-month reprieve as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. The Morrison government has delayed the implementation of commitments associated with the banking royal commission so lenders can concentrate on addressing the COVID-19 crisis. The new timeline will see legislation scheduled for introduction before 30 June, moved to December 2020, and measures originally set for implementation by December shifted to June 2021.

archiveTopNews.title: Employers could be held liable for workers who contract COVID-19
archiveTopNews.summary: Employers could be held liable for workers who contract coronavirus on the job, lawyers say. As restrictions ease and workers prepare to return to offices, employers are being warned they need to adhere to the health guidelines or they face serious legal trouble. Maurice Blackburn principal lawyer Liberty Sanger said even in a pandemic, employers must provide a safe workplace and if they ignore hygiene and social distancing guidelines, they could be sued by employees who suffer long-term impacts.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus distancing restrictions to ease across Queensland for Mother's Day
archiveTopNews.summary: Queensland will again ease COVID-19 contact restrictions from Mother's Day this Sunday to allow up to five members from one household to visit another home. Multiple families can visit the same household as long as it is at different times. Chief Medical Officer Jeannette Young said the 50-kilometre limit on travel would also be lifted "if you're visiting another household". "But you can't go out into that community. You can only go to that residence, visit there, and leave," Dr Young said.

archiveTopNews.title: South Australia ends 14-day coronavirus-free streak with new case contracted in UK
archiveTopNews.summary: South Australia has recorded its first new coronavirus case in a fortnight after a man who returned from the United Kingdom in March tested positive. SA Health believes the man in his 70s acquired COVID–19 overseas, but developed "very mild" symptoms, including a loss of taste and smell sensations, after his return on March 20. The latest diagnosis brings the total number of positive coronavirus cases in the state to 439.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus numbers have put Australia's growth factor back above one — should we be worried?
archiveTopNews.summary: For the first time in more than a month, the 'growth factor' for COVID-19 cases in Australia has risen above one - it is currently 1.04. That is, there are more new cases this week than there were last week. Put simply, growth factor is a measure of how quickly the number of new cases is rising or falling — and the critical thing to remember is that we want to keep it below one. Catherine Bennett, the chair of epidemiology at Deakin University, says that the importance of this number at this stage in the outbreak is really as a signal that something's changed over the last seven days and what we expect that to be now is probably clusters of cases. She stated that this means that we've got work to do — we've got to make sure that the reason it's above one is well under control.

archiveTopNews.title: Covidsafe app is not working properly on iPhones, authorities admit
archiveTopNews.summary: Australians running the COVIDSafe contact tracing app on iPhones may not be recording all the data required if they don’t have the app running in the foreground or they are using an older model phone, the government has admitted. More than 5.1 million Australians have downloaded and registered to use the app on iPhone and Android devices, and, while the Android version works while running in the background (ie, not open on the screen), the iPhone version works best when the app is open on the screen and the phone is unlocked.

archiveTopNews.title: WA marks one week without new coronavirus cases
archiveTopNews.summary: Western Australia has marked one week of no new COVID-19 cases, as the state government expands a study testing asymptomatic people. Only 14 active cases remain in the state, including seven patients in Perth hospitals, while 528 people have recovered. Premier Mark McGowan stated that while the state government was focused on loosening restrictions that would boost the economy and keep people safe, the hard border closure would remain in place for now.

archiveTopNews.title: Prime Minister Scott Morrison labels herd immunity a death sentence
archiveTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison says the herd immunity approach to dealing with the COVID-19 virus is a "death sentence." Mr Morrison once again praised Australia's response to the coronavirus crisis, saying we've done very well compared to other nations. The Prime Minister also questioned the aggressive interrogation of a New South Wales health official at the Ruby Princess inquiry yesterday. Furthermore, the Prime Minister said he will continue to push for a global inquiry into the origins of COVID-19.

archiveTopNews.title: Government releases proposed laws to underpin privacy protections for COVIDSafe app
archiveTopNews.summary: The government has released a draft of its legislative backing to privacy and data protections for the COVIDSafe tracing app. It proposes to make it illegal for anyone to refuse a person without the app entry to a public place, ban them from an activity or refuse to buy or sell goods and services to them.The legislation would also make it an offence to access the data without proper authorisation and for the data to be stored anywhere outside of Australia, and says records of the Bluetooth "handshakes" a user's phone makes with people they come in close contact with must be deleted after 21 days or upon request. All offences have a maximum penalty of five years in jail, a $63,00 fine or both.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison maps out Australia's path back to work
archiveTopNews.summary: Australia has succeeded in containing the coronavirus outbreak but now needs to flatten a new "curve" of unemployment, Prime Minister Scott Morrison says. "We now need to get one million Australians back to work, that is the curve we need to address," Mr Morrison said. "As long as these restrictions are in place, they are costing our economy some $4 billion each week ... it certainly puts enormous pressure, as it should, on the timetable as we seek to move Australia back to that safe economy."

archiveTopNews.title: Coles extends trading hours as panic-buying eases
archiveTopNews.summary: Coles will extend trading hours at the majority of its stores. Almost 200 stores will begin trading from 6am, the supermarket giant confirmed this morning. The news comes as panic-buying across the country eases and stores begin replenishing empty shelves. Coles Chief Operations Officer, Matt Swindells said more stock on shelves and improved customer behaviour meant dedicated community hours could also be lifted.

archiveTopNews.title: Jacinda Ardern says travel with Australia amid coronavirus pandemic could have 'huge advantages'
archiveTopNews.summary: New Zealand's Prime Minister will tomorrow join the Australian Government's National Cabinet meeting to discuss the proposal. Australia and New Zealand have earned international praise for their success containing the COVID-19 outbreak, and both governments are now seriously contemplating lifting restrictions on flights between the countries. Ms Arden has declared that a trans-Tasman travel bubble would offer "huge advantages" as both countries intensify negotiations over possibly opening borders later this year. She would not be drawn on the possible timing, adding that there was no chance of flights resuming in the next few weeks.

archiveTopNews.title: Queensland children to return to classroom in two stages - starting next week
archiveTopNews.summary: Community kindy, prep as well as Years 1, 11 and 12 will return to classrooms in Queensland next Monday, May 11, as part of the state government plan to reopen schools in two stages over three weeks. Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk outlined the proposed agenda on Monday, with a reassessment to be done on May 15, before Years 2-10 were due to return to school on Monday, May 25. Chief health officer Dr Jeannette Young said the theory behind the two-stage school reopening was to get the pick-up and drop-off procedures, which were of most concern for potential COVID-19 transmission, perfected with the younger children while there were fewer students around and before the remaining students return.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison urged to extend coronavirus assistance to one million 'vulnerable' temporary visa holders
archiveTopNews.summary: Human rights and advocacy groups say Australia's more than one million temporary visa holders will be at risk of homelessness if the government does not extend its coronavirus relief measures to the most vulnerable. Almost 200 Australian community groups have signed an open letter to Prime Minister Scott Morrison, urging him to include more than one million refugees, asylum seekers and vulnerable communities in the government's coronavirus response.

archiveTopNews.title: South Australian playgrounds to reopen after 11-day coronavirus-free streak
archiveTopNews.summary: South Australia's Chief Public Health Officer, Nicola Spurrier, has recommended reopening parks, playgrounds and equipment from today after the state recorded 11 days without a new coronavirus case. Most — but not all — councils taped off playgrounds and fitness outdoor equipment during the pandemic. Dr Spurrier said reopening public play spaces was an indication of the community's efforts to slow the spread of coronavirus.

archiveTopNews.title: Flight Centre waives cancellation fees after consumer watchdog threatens legal action
archiveTopNews.summary: The consumer watchdog was preparing to launch court action against Flight Centre for charging $300 fees to process Covid-19 refunds before the company agreed to end the practice. Flight Centre angered many of its customers by charging the $300 fee to each person for each element of their trip that was cancelled due to the pandemic and associated travel restrictions. Flight Centre on Saturday announced it will no longer charge the fee if the travel provider cancels its service.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus app tracing capability not operational, despite 4 million downloads
archiveTopNews.summary: More than 4 million people have downloaded the COVIDSafe app, but the information it collects is not yet available to state and territory health officials. He said the app was already logging users' close contacts, and that information could be accessed at a later date. The app will not be fully functional until states and territories finalise rules on privacy, and final IT testing is conducted.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus cases revealed in Victorian paramedic and cluster of Melbourne abattoir workers
archiveTopNews.summary: The number of coronavirus cases in Victoria continues to inch up as a paramedic tests positive to the virus and health authorities investigate a cluster at a meat processing plant. The unnamed Melbourne meat processing plant has been temporarily closed after eight employees tested positive to coronavirus, including three in the past 24 hours. A spokesperson said there was nothing to indicate that the paramedic that tested positive had acquired the virus from patient contact, however, as a precaution, five paramedics who came into contact with them are also in isolation.

archiveTopNews.title: Public health alert issued over new Queensland coronavirus case
archiveTopNews.summary: A plane passenger returning to Brisbane from Melbourne has tested positive to COVID-19 overnight, triggering a public health alert. State health authorities are urgently tracing people the infected traveller was in contact with on Qantas flight QF614 from Melbourne to Brisbane on April 22. Those who travelled in rows 19, 20, 21, 22 and 23 are urged to contact Queensland Health.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia's aged care centres to get $205 million to stay open during coronavirus crisis
archiveTopNews.summary: Aged care providers will get another $205 million from the federal government to help them keep centres open to visitors during the coronavirus crisis. Providers will receive $900 per occupied bed under the new funding package, with regional centres offered $1,350 per resident. The national cabinet has also released a draft visitor access code, which is open for comment until May 11, to ensure families and carers can visit residents in nursing homes.

archiveTopNews.title: Morrison says 'early mark' of eased restrictions depends on uptake of Covidsafe tracing app
archiveTopNews.summary: Scott Morrison has offered Australians an “early mark” to ease Covid-19 restrictions next week while warning a return to normality will depend on uptake of the Covidsafe contact tracing app. Morrison also revealed that net overseas migration is down 30% and is expected to fall by 80% in 2020-21, both compared with 2018-19, in a sign the economic contraction from Covid-19 will last much longer than restrictions to social life. Treasury officials and the Reserve Bank both estimate that unemployment is set to top 10%.

archiveTopNews.title: Marise Payne, Julie Bishop urge calm in tense relations with China over coronavirus origins
archiveTopNews.summary: There are rising tensions between Australia and China, which began when Australia started pressing for an investigation into the origin of COVID-19. Foreign Minister Marise Payne says that global co-operation not economic coercion is the appropriate way to resolve the dispute over an international investigation into COVID-19. Ms Payne said she rejected the approach of ambassador Cheng Jingye, who floated a Chinese consumer boycott of Australian products in retaliation to tension over the probe, targeting the crucial agriculture, education and tourism markets.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus recovery: ACT becomes first state or territory to be free of known cases of COVID-19
archiveTopNews.summary: The ACT has become the first Australian jurisdiction to be free of all known cases of COVID-19. After a total of 106 diagnoses and three deaths in the ACT, Jan Stoop, the last Canberran to test positive to coronavirus, has recovered. ACT Chief Health Officer Dr Kerryn Coleman welcomed the local elimination of the virus, and reiterated that the pandemic is ongoing, emphasising it is important not to undo the work that has been done.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia's coronavirus restrictions are easing. Here's what you can do in your state this weekend
archiveTopNews.summary: Millions of Australians are set to enjoy more freedoms over the coming days as COVID-19 restrictions are eased, but the rules are different in every state and territory. This article outlines the restrictions that have been dropped state-by-state.

archiveTopNews.title: More than 1.3 million Australians on jobseeker as Senate inquiry calls for permanent increase to rate
archiveTopNews.summary: More than 1.3 million people are now receiving unemployed benefits across the country, with that number expected to reach about 1.7 million in September. The government faces growing pressure to consider a permanent increase to the jobseeker payment, which has received a temporary $550 per fortnight boost for about six months.

archiveTopNews.title: Prime Minister Scott Morrison flags easing of coronavirus restrictions in near future
archiveTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrisonsaid Australia was "on the road back" to an economy safe from COVID-19 and that success could mean easing restrictions soon, noting that one of the most important tools to help fast-track restrictions being lifted was the Government's COVIDSafe tracing app. He also ruled out international travel restarting any time soon, with the potential exception of travel to New Zealand.

archiveTopNews.title: Australians urged not to neglect mental health during 'pressure cooker' coronavirus pandemic
archiveTopNews.summary: he government's top advisor on suicide prevention is urging Australians not to neglect their mental health during the coronavirus pandemic. Chief executive of the National Mental Health Commission Christine Morgan on Wednesday revealed new statistics showing the overall use of mental health services has been declining in Australia during the COVID-19 outbreak, which she speculated was due to people who would normally be using mental health services are not actually going out and doing those visits. Although the overall use of mental health services had declined, there had been an encouraging rise in the use of telehealth services such as Beyond Blue, Ms Morgan said.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW coronavirus restrictions will be partially lifted to allow limited visiting
archiveTopNews.summary: People in New South Wales will soon be able to visit each other as the premier, Gladys Berejiklian, joins other state and territory governments in easing lockdown laws. In a press conference on Tuesday morning, Berejiklian said that since NSW infection rates remained low, two adults and their children would be able to travel to other homes to visit. A spokeswoman from the premier’s office said guests were allowed to stay overnight and there were no restrictions on distance.

archiveTopNews.title: Hundreds return to Sydney's famous Bondi Beach as coronavirus restrictions are eased
archiveTopNews.summary: Hundreds of surfers have returned to the water at Bondi for the first time since the beach was closed five weeks ago due to COVID-19 restrictions. People are now permitted to swim or surf at Bondi and Bronte, and surf only at Tamarama, between 7am and 5pm on weekdays. Access is via designated entry and exit points and the sand remains out of bounds for sunbathers.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia's aged care residents caught in standoff over visits during coronavirus
archiveTopNews.summary: Aged care residents and their families are caught in the crossfire of an escalating stand-off between the federal government and the sector over visiting rights during the Covid-19 pandemic. Ahead of a meeting with providers on Friday, the government suggested it was prepared to force homes to allow each resident two visitors a day, in line with official health guidelines, if operators did not ease their own rules. On Monday, a coalition of 1,000 aged care homes and their representatives roundly rejected the government’s request and disputed claims elevated by the prime minister that some homes were simply locking residents in their rooms.

archiveTopNews.title: More than two million Australians download COVIDSafe contact tracing app
archiveTopNews.summary: As of Monday 4pm, 1.89 million Australians had downloaded the COVID-19 tracer app, which aims to help health officials identify people who may have come into contact with someone with the disease. Chief medical officer Brendan Murphy called the result a positive start to bolstering the public health response against the coronavirus. The government has said 40 per cent - or some 10 million people - would be needed for contact-tracing to be most successful.

archiveTopNews.title: What is COVIDSafe, Australia's controversial new contact tracing app?
archiveTopNews.summary: On Sunday, the Federal Government launched a mobile phone app it hopes will improve the tracing of coronavirus cases and the people they come in contact with. The COVIDSafe app aims to identify people who may have come into contact with someone who has coronavirus so the user can give the information to health authorities. The COVIDSafe app is based on Singapore's Tracetogether software, which records the Bluetooth connections a phone makes with others, as part of what's being called a "Bluetooth handshake". But the launch came amid concerns about the technology and the data it would collect.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus stay-at-home restrictions to be eased in Queensland
archiveTopNews.summary: Queensland will relax some stay-at-home restrictions from midnight on Friday with less than 100 active COVID-19 cases across the state. Family picnics and weekend drives are back on the agenda for Queenslanders starting next weekend after just three COVID-19 cases were recorded overnight. Premier Annastacia Palaszcuk says the easing of restrictions would start at midnight on Friday and people would be limited to travel about 50km from their residence and “limited to members of your own household”.

archiveTopNews.title: WA to allow gatherings of up to 10 people as COVID-19 cases drop
archiveTopNews.summary: Western Australia will relax its coronavirus restrictions to allow up to 10 people to gather for non-work activities, as the state recorded another day of no new COVID-19 cases. Premier Mark McGowan said it was a "cautious relaxation" of restrictions, acknowledging it had been difficult for everyone, but especially the elderly, to not see family and friends during the pandemic. From Monday, non-contact recreational activities such as picnics in parks, fishing, boating, hiking and camping will be allowed but people must comply with travel restrictions. Ten people will be allowed at weddings and the 10-person limit remains for funerals.

archiveTopNews.title: Australians turn out for driveway dawn service to mark Anzac Day in time of coronavirus
archiveTopNews.summary: Thousands take part in a Covid-19-friendly but lonelier than usual commemoration of Gallipoli. The idea for the driveway dawn service came from two former Townsville defence force personnel, Warrant Officer Terry James and Brigadier Bill Sowry, who were discussing a Covid-19-friendly way to commemorate the day on social media. The plan quickly gained popularity and RSL branches and politicians across the country encouraged people to take part.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia ramps up coronavirus testing to include anyone with respiratory symptoms
archiveTopNews.summary: Following a national cabinet meeting on Friday, Chief Medical Officer Brendan Murphy announced all states and territories would expand their testing criteria to ensure any community transmission was being picked up. The meeting also discussed reports of aged care facilities refusing visitors and locking residents in their rooms. Prime Minister Scott Morrison said if facilities that had gone beyond baseline coronavirus requirements did not return to that level and allow each resident two visitors a day, his government would make it mandatory.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison says social distancing rules do not apply to school classrooms
archiveTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison says the government's medical advice confirms social distancing requirements do not apply to classrooms, clearing the way for students to return to school.  While Australians have been told to keep 1.5 metres apart, or two arms' lengths, Mr Morrison said the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) had determined students did not need to abide by that advice in the classroom.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison says JobSeeker payment will be cut after pandemic
archiveTopNews.summary: Scott Morrison has indicated that the JobSeeker allowance, formerly known as Newstart, will be reduced after the COVID-19 pandemic.
